<div id="S001" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec-type_intro NLM_sec_level_1">
 <h2 id="_i2" class="section-heading-2">1. Introduction</h2>
 <p>Many optimal control tasks for engineering problems require the solution of nonconvex optimisation problems (OPs), which are harder to solve than convex ones. The nonconvexity can have various causes. Restrictions in the operating range of actuators can result in nonconvex sets. Nonconvexity can also be caused by nonlinear system dynamics resulting in nonlinear and thus nonconvex equality constraints. Since a fast and robust computation of the optimum is always desirable and even essential for real-time control applications, convexification represents a fundamental field in optimal control. Convex OPs can be solved efficiently and robustly with elaborate solvers capable of computing the global optimum with high accuracy and generally short computation times. Various convexification methods have been proposed, which generally solve nonconvex problems by iteratively solving convex substitute problems.</p>
 <div id="S001-S2001" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i3">1.1. Literature survey on convexification techniques</h3>
  <p>Lossless convexification (LC) transforms a special class of nonconvex sets into convex ones by lifting the optimisation space into a higher dimension using additional decision variables&nbsp;(Acikmese &amp;&nbsp;Blackmore,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0001" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2011</a></span>; Acikmese &amp;&nbsp;Ploen,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0002" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2007</a></span>). The approach is applicable to a special class of nonconvex sets: sets generated by removing a convex subset from a convex set. This has been used in aeronautic optimal control applications to successfully convexify annulus-shaped sets. An overview regarding the individual findings on LC is given in&nbsp;Raković and&nbsp;Levine&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0042" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2018</a></span>, p.338).</p>
  <p>Another often employed technique for convex approximation is linearisation since linear objectives and constraints are convex&nbsp;(Boyd &amp;&nbsp;Vandenberghe,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0005" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2004</a></span>). However, linearisation can introduce conservativeness and infeasibility since the resulting accuracy strongly depends on the nonlinearity as well as the linearisation point. Various linearisation techniques have been used to approximate nonlinear systems when applying optimal control methods. In the simplest case, the system is linearised at each time instant around the current operating point, exemplarily implemented in&nbsp;Falcone et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0015" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2007</a></span>). However, the model approximation is only sufficiently valid in a close neighbourhood around the linearisation point. With increasing distance to this point, the linearised OP can strongly differ from the original one. Thus, this approach can result in poor controller performance or even lead to infeasibility or instability.</p>
  <p>In order to mitigate linearisation errors, the system can be linearised around predicted trajectories resulting in efficiently solvable quadratic programming (QP) problems&nbsp;(Diehl et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0012" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2005</a></span>; Seki et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0049" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2004</a></span>). One method using iterative linearisation around trajectories in a model predictive control (MPC) setup is the so-called real-time iteration approach&nbsp;(Diehl et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0012" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2005</a></span>). The procedure assumes that at every time instant, the shifted solution from the preceding time instant represents a good initial guess close to the actual solution. Thus, a full Newton-step is taken, omitting underlying line-search routines to reduce computation time.</p>
  <p>Another iterative scheme linearising around changing trajectories has been presented in&nbsp;Mao et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0033" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2016</a></span>). Starting from an initial trajectory, the nonlinear system equations are successively linearised around the solution computed in the preceding iteration. Adding virtual control inputs eliminates the artificial infeasibility introduced by the linearisation. Furthermore, including trust regions ensures that the solution does not deviate too much from the preceding succession and thus the linearisation represents a valid approximation. This avoids unboundedness of the linearised OP. Based on the ratio between actual objective change and linearised objective change, the algorithm adjusts the trust regions and terminates if the objectives coincide.</p>
  <p>A linearise-and-project (LnP) approach has been used in&nbsp;Mao et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0032" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>) to resolve the nonconvexity due to nonlinear system equations and nonconvex constraints. The approach presumes convex functions for the right-hand side of the system differential equations. The satisfaction of the system dynamics is ensured by relaxing the corresponding equality constraints into inequality constraints and using exact penalty functions. In an iterative optimisation routine, the computed solution is projected onto the constraints in each iteration to gain adequate linearisation points.</p>
  <p>Instead of linearising the system equations around trajectories, a linear input-to-state behaviour can be enforced via feedback-linearisation&nbsp;(Khalil,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0023" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2002</a></span>, p.&nbsp;505). An optimal control method can then be used to optimally control the linearised system in an outer control loop&nbsp;(Del Re et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0011" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1993</a></span>). However, it is possible that the nonlinear mapping of the feedback linearisation transforms originally convex objective and constraint functions into nonconvex ones&nbsp;(Simon et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0050" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2013</a></span>). Then, the exact satisfaction of these constraints requires a nonlinear programming (NLP) strategy or an iterative scheme which both eliminate the computational benefits of the feedback-linearisation&nbsp;(Kurtz &amp;&nbsp;Henson,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0026" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1997</a></span>). One possible solution to this problem is approximating these constraints by estimating future inputs based on the preceding time instant within an MPC scheme&nbsp;(Kurtz &amp;&nbsp;Henson,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0026" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1997</a></span>; Schnelle &amp;&nbsp;Eberhard,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0045" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2015</a></span>). The authors in&nbsp;Simon et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0050" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2013</a></span>) have proposed an alternative&nbsp;MPC approach that replaces such nonlinear constraints via dynamically generated local inner polytopic approximations rendering the OP convex.</p>
  <p>Fuzzy MPC with models of Takagi-Sugeno (TS) type has been successfully used for nonlinear&nbsp;MPC. The TS modelling procedure enables an accurate approximation of nonlinear systems by using data combined with model knowledge&nbsp;(Tanaka &amp;&nbsp;Wang,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0051" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2004</a></span>). The modelling approach decomposes nonlinear models into several local approximations which are blended together via fuzzy rules. However, this requires the system matrices to be stored, thus occupying more memory. Although TS fuzzy models have been successfully used in nonlinear&nbsp;MPC, computation time can be strongly reduced by linearising the TS models around predicted trajectories&nbsp;(Mollov et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0037" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2004</a></span>,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0038" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1998</a></span>). The resulting convex QP problem can be solved efficiently while guaranteeing convergence via a line search mechanism.</p>
  <p>Differential dynamic programming initially linearises the system equations around a nominal trajectory. Starting from the terminal state, a backward pass identifies the optimal controller gains of a linear quadratic regulator at each time step using the linearised system. Subsequently, a forward pass computes new nominal trajectories via numerical integration using the controller gains previously computed in the backward pass. This procedure is repeated until convergence. Iterative linear quadratic regulators are a variant of differential dynamic programming&nbsp;(Mayne,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0035" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1973</a></span>). The main difference is that only first-order derivatives are used for the approximation of the system dynamics via Taylor expansion instead of second-order ones which decreases computation time&nbsp;(Tassa et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0052" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2012</a></span>). Constrained versions of this optimisation technique have been presented in&nbsp;Tassa et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0053" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2014</a></span>), Xie et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0057" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>) and Chen et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0007" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>).</p>
  <p>Lifting-based MPC methods represent another class of linearisation approaches used for solving optimal control problems (OCPs) with nonlinear systems. By lifting the nonlinear dynamics to a space of higher dimension, the evolution of the system can be represented in a bilinear or linear fashion via Carleman linearisation or the Koopman operator framework, respectively. Representing the nonlinear system equations via bilinear terms enables the analytical computation of sensitivity functions&nbsp;(Armaou &amp;&nbsp;Ataei,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0003" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2014</a></span>) and of solutions&nbsp;(Fang &amp;&nbsp;Armaou,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0016" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2015</a></span>) which speeds up computation time. The Koopman&nbsp;MPC approach employs a linear predictor of higher order, which is identified via data sets, to approximate the nonlinear system&nbsp;(Korda &amp;&nbsp;Mezić,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0024" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2018</a></span>). The resulting larger OCP is condensed by eliminating the state decision variables and then solved for the input decision variables using linear&nbsp;MPC. Hence, this method enables a fast solution of nonlinear OCPs. However, identifying the linear Koopman system involves some effort requiring an adequate selection of basis functions, non-recurrent data sets and the solution of convex OPs&nbsp;(Cibulka et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0008" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2019</a></span>). Furthermore, the Koopman&nbsp;MPC approach does not always outperform the standard&nbsp;MPC method using local linearisations&nbsp;(Cibulka et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0009" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020</a></span>). Depending on the dimension of the lifted states, both approaches can require the storage of a great number of offline computed matrices.</p>
  <p>Various local methods for solving nonconvex quadratically constrained quadratic programming (QCQP) problems have been summarised in&nbsp;d'Aspremont and&nbsp;Boyd&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0010" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2003</a></span>)&nbsp;and&nbsp;Park and&nbsp;Boyd&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0040" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>). A two-phase coordinate descent method first reduces the maximum constraint violation trying to find a feasible point. The second phase is restricted to feasible points only and searches in each iteration for a feasible point with a better objective function value. The convex-concave procedure (CCP) is a method for finding a local optimum for difference-of-convex programming problems, thus suitable for QCQP. The nonconvex part of the constraints is linearised rendering the constraints convex. In order to deal with infeasible initial guesses, penalty&nbsp;CCP relaxes the linearised constraints via slack variables and introduces a gradually increasing penalty objective for constraint violations. The alternating directions method of multipliers (ADMM) is a variant of the augmented Lagrangian method. It forms an equivalent OP by using auxiliary decision variables which must satisfy a consensus constraint. The objective function is augmented using switching indicator functions which penalise individual constraint violations. The augmented objective function terms are separated into two groups of decision variables. Instead of solving the proximal augmented Lagrangian function for both groups of decision variables simultaneously, the solution is computed using an alternating approach. First, the first group of decision variables is fixed and the problem is solved for the second group. Then, the solution of the second group is fixed and the problem is solved for the first one. The results are used for the dual variable update and the procedure is repeated. This alternating approach requires the solution of simplified&nbsp;QCQP problems enhancing computation time compared to simultaneously solving for both groups of decision variables.</p>
  <p>Convexification measures for sequential quadratic programming (SQP) approaches on a more algorithmic level have been presented in&nbsp;Verschueren&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0055" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2018</a></span>). Many QP solvers do not support an indefinite Hessian of the Lagrangian since then a descent direction is not guaranteed. The author has presented a structure-preserving convexification procedure for indefinite Hessians. The convexified Hessian can be fed to any structure-exploiting QP solver&nbsp;(Verschueren,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0055" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2018</a></span>, p.&nbsp;39). Furthermore, sequential convex quadratic programming is proposed which uses second-order derivatives of convex objective functions and convex constraint functions to construct positive definite Hessians enabling the sequential solution of convex QP problems&nbsp;(Verschueren,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0055" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2018</a></span>, p.&nbsp;70).</p>
  <p>Using the notion of space decomposition for convexification, global optimisation (GO) techniques have similarities with the convexification approach presented in this article. In order to compute the global optimum of continuous, nonconvex OPs, spatial branch-and-bound (BnB) techniques iteratively divide the search space into increasingly smaller subdomains (Liberti,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0027" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2008</a></span>; Liberti &amp;&nbsp;Maculan,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0028" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2006</a></span>; Ryoo &amp;&nbsp;Sahinidis,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0043" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1995</a></span>; Tawarmalani &amp;&nbsp;Sahinidis,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0054" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2002</a></span>). A convex relaxation of nonconvex functions is applied on each subdomain. The efficiently solvable relaxed problem provides a lower bound of the objective function for the corresponding subdomain. The comparison with an upper bound, which can be computed using local optimisation techniques, determines if a further space subdivision is necessary. Thus, this technique searches over a tree whose nodes correspond to individual relaxed problems which consider different subdomains. Comparing the solutions on the individual subdomains provides the global solution. Tree nodes are excluded on the fly based on the evaluation of the lower and upper bounds of the individual nodes eliminating the need to explore the entire domain.</p>
 </div>
 <div id="S001-S2002" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i4">1.2. Contribution</h3>
  <p>In this article, a novel successive convexification method called space splitting convexification (SSC) is proposed aiming at reducing the computation time required to solve nonconvex OPs. The key contribution of the approach is the space decomposition procedure which provides a piecewise linear approximation of the original, nonconvex problem by introducing auxiliary decision variables and absolute value constraints (AVCs). These AVCs possess a beneficial structure for linearisation and point projection onto constraints. The AVCs are transferred to the objective function using the concept of exact penalty functions and then iteratively linearised around changing points. The linearisation of the AVCs results in a binary decision: wrong or right sign of the AVC-linearisation. In each iteration, the computed solution is projected onto the AVCs and the sign is corrected if necessary enabling the linearisation errors to vanish in subsequent iterations. This concludes the iterative solution of a convex QP problem or even linear programming (LP) problem if the original objective is linear. The violation of the linearised AVCs serves as feedback if the correct sign was chosen which is used as an indicator for convergence. The approach is capable of considering two types of nonconvexities. Firstly, a class of nonconvex sets that can be split into convex subsets which are called zonally convex sets (ZCSs) in this article. Such sets arise for instance when semi-active actuators are used. Secondly, equality constraints with possibly multiple but univariate nonlinearities. As already mentioned, a common source for these nonlinear equality constraints are nonlinear system equations when applying optimal control methods. Requiring only simple mathematical operations, the AVC-projection is of linear computational complexity. Furthermore, the binary nature of the AVC-linearisation generally results in few superordinate iterations. Thus, the SSC algorithm greatly reduces computation time enabling an efficient solution in polynomial-time. Furthermore, robust initialisation properties are given since the initial guess is not required to be feasible. The algorithm converges under certain conditions to local optima of the piecewise linear substitute problem, which represents a scalable approximation of the original problem. However, being a local solution method, the computed local solution generally depends on the provided initial guess. For good initialisations, the algorithm computes solutions which are close to the global optimum.</p>
 </div>
 <div id="S001-S2003" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i5">1.3. Article structure</h3>
  <p>The article is organised as follows. The novel successive convexification method is presented in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002">2</a>. Starting with the general formulation of optimal control problems, the original static OP for the numerical solution of the optimal control task is presented in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2001">2.1</a>. Afterwards, Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2002">2.2</a> derives the successive convexification algorithm and provides a proof of convergence. The specific application of the SSC algorithm to two-dimensional ZCSs and nonlinear equality constraints is illustrated in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2003">2.3</a>. Remarks on the computation time of the algorithm are given in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2004">2.4</a>. The comparison of the SSC approach with existing methods in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2005">2.5</a> concludes the theoretical part of the article. Using a single mass oscillator (SMO) application as an example, the SSC algorithm is compared with the NLP solver <i>IPOPT</i>&nbsp;(Wächter &amp;&nbsp;Biegler,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0056" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2006</a></span>) in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S003">3</a>. The required NLP problem and QP problem are defined in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S003-S2001">3.1</a> and the corresponding results are discussed in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S003-S2002">3.2</a>. Furthermore, the sensitivity regarding initial guesses is analysed in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S003-S2003">3.3</a> and rotated space splitting is briefly addressed in&nbsp;Section&nbsp;<a href="#S003-S2004">3.4</a>. The article closes with concluding remarks in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S004">4</a>. In order to promote swift comprehension, a table of notation is included at the end of the article.</p>
 </div>
</div>
<div id="S002" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1">
 <h2 id="_i6" class="section-heading-2">2. Space splitting convexification</h2>

   </math></span>. An optimal control trajectory&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0003.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0003.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mrow>
     <mrow>
      <mtext mathvariant="bold">
       u
      </mtext>
     </mrow>
    </mrow><mo>
     (
    </mo><mi>
     t
    </mi><mo>
     )
    </mo>
   </math></span> for a system described by&nbsp;(<a href="#M0001">1</a>) and time interval <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0004.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0004.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mi>
     t
    </mi><mo>
     ∈
    </mo><mo>
     [
    </mo><msub>
     <mi>
      t
     </mi>
     <mn>
      0
     </mn>
    </msub><mo>
     ,
    </mo><msub>
     <mi>
      t
     </mi>
     <mi>
      f
     </mi>
    </msub><mo>
     ]
    </mo>
   </math></span> can be computed by solving a dynamic OP of following form: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0002.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0002.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0002" class="disp-formula-label">(2a) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
     <mtr>
      <mtd>
       <munder>

        </mo>

   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0005.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0005" class="disp-formula-label">(2d) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

      <mtd></mtd>

       </mo>
      </mtd>
     </mtr>
    </mtable>
   </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0005" class="disp-formula-label">(2d) </span></span></span></span>The performance index&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0005.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0005.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mrow>
     <mover>
      <mi>
       J
      </mi>
      <mo>
       ~
      </mo>
     </mover>
    </mrow>
   </math></span> in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0002">2a</a>) to be minimised is comprised of the terminal cost function&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0006.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0006.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mi>
     ϑ
    </mi>
   </math></span> and the intermediate cost term&nbsp;<i>ϕ</i>. Equality constraint&nbsp;(<a href="#M0003">2b</a>) ensures that the system equations&nbsp;(<a href="#M0001">1</a>) are satisfied. General equality constraints <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0007.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0007.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mrow>
     <mover>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         c
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mo>
       ~
      </mo>
     </mover>
    </mrow><mo>
     ∈
    </mo><msup>
     <mrow>
      <mi mathvariant="double-struck">
       R
      </mi>
     </mrow>
     <mrow>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        n
       </mi>
       <mi>
        c
       </mi>
      </msub>
     </mrow>
    </msup>
   </math></span> and inequality constraints <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0008.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0008.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <mrow>
     <mover>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         h
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mo>
       ~
      </mo>
     </mover>
    </mrow><mo>
     ∈
    </mo><msup>
     <mrow>
      <mi mathvariant="double-struck">
       R
      </mi>
     </mrow>
     <mrow>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        n
       </mi>
       <mi>
        h
       </mi>
      </msub>
     </mrow>
    </msup>
   </math></span> are included via&nbsp;(<a href="#M0004">2c</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0005">2d</a>), respectively. Solving the dynamic OP&nbsp;(2) analytically is generally only possible for simple problems. Thus, dynamic OPs are mostly solved numerically via direct or indirect methods&nbsp;(Sedlacek et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0048" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020c</a></span>). While direct methods solve the original OP, indirect methods deduce a boundary-value problem which is analytically derived from the optimality conditions. A discretisation of trajectories via collocation or shooting can be used to obtain a static OP. Collocation methods employ decision variables for the inputs and states at discrete time points and deduce the trajectory via polynomial interpolation between these points. Single shooting methods only employ decision variables for the inputs and compute the corresponding state trajectories via numerical integration. Multiple shooting methods divide the time interval into subintervals on which the numerical integration is performed. The states at the interval margins represent additional decision variables and continuity constraints are introduced to ensure that the boundary points of the individual integration segments coincide. A direct collocation method is employed in this article due to the simpler initialisation of direct methods and the increased sparsity of collocation methods.</p>
 <div id="S002-S2001" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i12">2.1. Problem formulation</h3>
  <p>Using separated Hermite-Simpson collocation with a discretisation into <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

    </math></span> concludes the convexity of the objective. Collocation constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0008">4b</a>) ensure that the system equations&nbsp;(<a href="#M0001">1</a>) are satisfied. For Hermite-Simpson collocation, these equality constraints are given by <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi mathvariant="normal">
       Δ
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mi>

       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </msub><msub>

     </msub>
    </math></span>(Betts,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0004" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2010</a></span>; Kelly,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0022" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>). The SSC approach considers nonlinear right-hand sides of the form <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>

    <math>
     <mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mtext mathvariant="bold">
        k
       </mtext>
      </mrow>
     </mrow><mo>
      ,
     </mo><msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>

        </mi>
       </msub>
      </mrow>
     </msup>
    </math></span>. Therein <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0022.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0022.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         f
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         p
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         w
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         l
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> represents a composition of univariate nonlinearities that can be depicted or approximated by piecewise linear curves. For simplicity, it is assumed that the remaining equality constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0009">4c</a>) are affine in the decision variables. The inequality constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0010">4d</a>) are required to be convex in the decision variables. However, aiming at constructing a QP problem, it is assumed below that the inequality constraints are even affine. This stricter assumption can be posed without loss of generality, since convex inequality constraints can be approximated via a polyhedron using multiple affine functions&nbsp;(Boyd &amp;&nbsp;Vandenberghe,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0005" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2004</a></span>, p.&nbsp;32). The inequalities&nbsp;(<a href="#M0011">4e</a>) depict ZCSs, which are nonconvex sets that can be split into convex subsets.</p>
 </div>
 <div id="S002-S2002" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i21">2.2. Successive convexification procedure</h3>
  <p>Considering the standard form of convex OPs&nbsp;(Boyd &amp;&nbsp;Vandenberghe,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0005" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2004</a></span>, p.&nbsp;136), all equality constraints must be affine in the decision variables to enable the convexity of the problem. Hence, a nonlinear right-hand side of the system equations&nbsp;(<a href="#M0001">1</a>) results in nonlinear equality constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0012">5</a>), yielding a nonconvex OP. Furthermore, the nonconvex inequality constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0011">4e</a>) also prohibit a convex problem. The SSC algorithm iteratively solves a convex substitute problem which is derived from the original problem&nbsp;(4) as schematically illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0001">1</a>. The core idea of this concept is considering the transformed problem&nbsp;(15) which represents a piecewise linear approximation of the original problem&nbsp;(4). This transformation is achieved by introducing space splitting constraints. These constraints are nonconvex but render the original constraints convex. Furthermore, they possess an advantageous structure which is exploited by the algorithm. In order to deal with the remaining nonconvexity, the nonconvex space splitting constraints are transferred to the objective following the theory of exact penalty functions. The resulting problem&nbsp;(19) possesses a convex feasible set but a nonconvex objective. Thus, the nonconvex part of the objective is iteratively linearised around points that are adjusted based on the previous iterate using an intermediate projection routine. This yields the convex problem&nbsp;(22), which is sequentially solved within the SSC algorithm. A smoothable absolute value function is introduced <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0014.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0014.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0014" class="disp-formula-label">(7) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

    </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0014" class="disp-formula-label">(7) </span></span></span></span>which recovers the true absolute value for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0023.gif" alt="">

       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> and (19)<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0025.gif" alt="">

      <mrow>

       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0001">1</a> apply <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0026.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0026.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">

     <msub>
      <mi>
       ϵ
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mi>
        s
       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      &gt;
     </mo><mn>
      0
     </mn>
    </math></span> to provide continuous differentiability for the validity of the optimality conditions legitimising the application of exact penalty functions. Afterwards, this smoothing is removed since it represents an approximation which is not required in problem&nbsp;(22) for continuous differentiability. The subsequent sections describe the problem transformation process in more detail.</p>
  <div id="S002-S2002-S3001" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3">
   <h4 class="section-heading-4" id="_i23">2.2.1. Space splitting constraints</h4>
   <p>Before presenting the individual OPs, the basic principle for the space splitting of a decision variable is illustrated in this section providing graphical support. If collocation is used, the inputs as well as states represent decision variables. Thus, the input space and the state space can be split. The splitting procedure is presented using <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0027.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0027.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
       <mo>
        ∈
       </mo>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          W
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mo>
        [
       </mo>
       <munder>
        <mi>
         w
        </mi>
        <mo>
         _
        </mo>
       </munder>
       <mo>
        ,
       </mo>
       <mover>
        <mi>
         w
        </mi>
        <mo accent="false">
         ¯
        </mo>
       </mover>
       <mo>
        ]
       </mo>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> as a representative decision variable which is split at the transition point&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0028.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0028.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mi>
       w
      </mi><mo>
       =
      </mo><msub>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          t
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          r
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span>. As illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0002">2</a>(a), the auxiliary decision variables <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0029.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <msub>
        <mi>

        </mi>
        <mrow>

          </mi>

        </mrow>
       </msub>

     </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     </math></span> are introduced aiming at satisfying the following relations: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

   <p></p><statement id="st1" content-type="lemma">
    Lemma 2.1 
    <p>The splitting relations&nbsp;(<a href="#M0015">8</a>) can be implemented via the splitting constraints <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0016.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0016.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0016" class="disp-formula-label">(9a) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
        <mtr>
         <mtd>
          <msub>
           <mi>
            g
           </mi>
           <mrow>
            <mtext>
             aff
            </mtext>
           </mrow>
          </msub>
         </mtd>
         <mtd>

    Proof.

   <p>The AVC&nbsp;(<a href="#M0017">9b</a>) is relaxed into a convex inequality constraint which can be depicted using two linear inequality constraints <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0020.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0020" class="disp-formula-label">(11a) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0020" class="disp-formula-label">(11a) </span></span></span></span>Furthermore, the linearisation of the AVC based on the result of the preceding iteration&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0033.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0033.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msubsup>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          p
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          r
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          e
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          v
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mo>
         ⋆
        </mo>
       </mrow>
      </msubsup>
     </math></span> is added as an additional objective term in form of an exact penalty function <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0021.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0021.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0021" class="disp-formula-label">(11b) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>

     <noscript>

     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0025.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0025" class="disp-formula-label">(13b) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
       <mtr>
        <mtd></mtd>
        <mtd>
         <msub>
          <mi>

          </mi>
          <mrow>
           <mi>
            s
           </mi>
          </mrow>
         </msub>
         <mi>
          τ
         </mi>
         <msub>
          <mi>

          </mi>
          <mi>

          </mi>
         </msub>
         <mo>

         </mo>
        </mtd>
       </mtr>
      </mtable>
     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0025" class="disp-formula-label">(13b) </span></span></span></span>Since adding slack variables increases the number of decision variables, this is not desirable from an implementation standpoint; however, it fosters comprehension. The relaxation of constraint&nbsp;(<a href="#M0024">13a</a>) via the slack variable&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0039.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0039.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        s
       </mi>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
      </msub>
     </math></span> is necessary to avoid infeasibility, which is illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0002">2</a>(b): Since <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0040.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0040.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">

      </mn>
     </math></span> holds, an unrelaxed constraint&nbsp;(<a href="#M0024">13a</a>) with&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0041.gif" alt="">

     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        s
       </mi>
       <mi>

       </mi>
      </msub><mo>
       ≡

       0
      </mn>
     </math></span> would only allow values satisfying&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0042.gif" alt="">

     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mover>
         <mi>
          w
         </mi>
         <mo>
          ~
         </mo>
        </mover>
       </mrow>
       <mo>
        ≤
       </mo>
       <mn>

       </mn>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0043.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0043.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        σ
       </mi>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mo>
       −
      </mo><mn>
       1
      </mn>
     </math></span> and only values&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0044.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0044.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mover>
        <mi>
         w
        </mi>
        <mo>
         ~
        </mo>
       </mover>
      </mrow><mo>
       ≥
      </mo><mn>
       0
      </mn>
     </math></span> for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0045.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0045.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        σ
       </mi>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mn>
       1
      </mn>
     </math></span>. However, the sign is based on the previous iteration and can thus be wrong. Then, a relaxation represented by the slack variable is necessary to allow values&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0046.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0046.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mover>
        <mi>
         w
        </mi>
        <mo>
         ~
        </mo>
       </mover>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> of the opposite region and avoid infeasibility. The sign is corrected for the subsequent iteration step to enable eradicating the additional objective&nbsp;(<a href="#M0025">13b</a>) and thus the slack variable. This concludes that the initial solution does not have to represent a feasible solution, which results in robust initialisation behaviour. The relaxation via the slack variable&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0047.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0047.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        s
       </mi>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
      </msub>
     </math></span> in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0024">13a</a>) corresponds to the violation of constraint&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0048.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0048.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        l
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          b
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> via&nbsp;(<a href="#M0022">11c</a>). The fact that the constraint violation will be large in case of a wrong sign is used as feedback for the algorithm. The algorithm will iterate until a feasible point satisfying <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0049.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0049.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        l
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          b
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       ≈
      </mo><mn>
       0
      </mn><mo>
       ≈
      </mo><msub>
       <mi>
        s
       </mi>
       <mi>
        w
       </mi>
      </msub>
     </math></span> is reached. Then, the additional objective&nbsp;(<a href="#M0022">11c</a>) vanishes.</p>
  </div>
  <div id="S002-S2002-S3002" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3">
   <h4 class="section-heading-4" id="_i37">2.2.2. Piecewise linear approximation of optimisation problem</h4>
   <p>The first step towards a convex OP is the derivation of a piecewise linear approximation of the original problem&nbsp;(4). This is achieved by using the concept of space splitting presented in the previous section. Since multiple decision variables can be split, the formulation of the OP is posed using the augmented vector of decision variables <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0026.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0026.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0026" class="disp-formula-label">(14) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>

        <mtext mathvariant="bold">

        </mtext>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0026" class="disp-formula-label">(14) </span></span></span></span>with the auxiliary decision variables&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0050.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0050.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mtext mathvariant="bold">
          w
         </mtext>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          u
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          x
         </mi>
         <mo>
          ,
         </mo>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          k
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       ∈
      </mo><msup>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="double-struck">
         R
        </mi>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <msub>
         <mi>
          n
         </mi>
         <mi>
          s
         </mi>
        </msub>
       </mrow>
      </msup>
     </math></span>. Therein some of the original states and inputs are excluded when they are depicted using affine transformations as illustrated in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2003-S3001">2.3.1</a>. The corresponding substitute problem is given for all <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0056.gif" alt="">

     <math>
      <mi mathvariant="bold">

      </mo><mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         z
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow><mo>
       )
      </mo>
     </math></span> in problem&nbsp;(15) represents the accumulation of the affine transformations <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0057.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi mathvariant="bold">
        Φ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         x
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0058.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0058.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi mathvariant="bold">
        Φ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        n
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         Φ
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mo>
       (
      </mo><msub>

      </msub>
     </math></span> yielding <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

     <math>
