            </mi>
           </mrow>
          </mrow>
         </mtd>
        </mtr>
       </mtable>
      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0059" class="disp-formula-label">(28) </span></span></span></span>since&nbsp;(<a href="#M0059">28</a>) holds at the latest from the value <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0137.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0137.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          Q
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi>
           Q
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          λ
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span> with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0138.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0138.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mrow>
         <mfenced open="∥" close="∥">
          <mrow>
           <mi mathvariant="normal">
            Δ
           </mi>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mtext mathvariant="bold">
              z
             </mtext>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
          </mrow>
         </mfenced>
        </mrow>
        <mrow></mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><mn>
        0
       </mn><mo>
        &lt;
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         ϵ
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          τ
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span>. This proves that&nbsp;(<a href="#M0057">26</a>) is a Cauchy sequence and thus converges&nbsp;(Zorich,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0059" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2016</a></span>, p.&nbsp;85). Hence, the solutions of the individual iterations can oscillate; however, this oscillation vanishes with an increasing number of iterations finally converging to a single point&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0139.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0139.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msup>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mtext mathvariant="bold">
           z
          </mtext>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mo>
          ⋆
         </mo>
        </mrow>
       </msup>
      </math></span>. Due to Lemma&nbsp;2.2, <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0140.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0140.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mtext mathvariant="bold">
           l
          </mtext>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           a
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           b
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           s
          </mi>
         </mrow>
         <mo>
          ,
         </mo>
         <mi>
          k
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mtext mathvariant="bold">
          0
         </mtext>
        </mrow>
       </mrow><mtext>
        &nbsp;
       </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">
        ∀
       </mi><mtext>
        &nbsp;
       </mtext><mi>
        k
       </mi><mo>
        ∈
       </mo><mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          K
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </math></span> concludes that this point satisfies <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0141.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0141.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mtext mathvariant="bold">
           g
          </mtext>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           a
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           b
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           s
          </mi>
         </mrow>
         <mo>
          ,
         </mo>
         <mi>
          k
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mtext mathvariant="bold">
          0
         </mtext>
        </mrow>
       </mrow><mtext>
        &nbsp;
       </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">
        ∀
       </mi><mtext>
        &nbsp;
       </mtext><mi>
        k
       </mi><mo>
        ∈
       </mo><mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          K
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </math></span>.</p>
   </statement>
   <p>Theorem&nbsp;2.2 concludes that the iterative solution of OP&nbsp;(<a href="#M0045">22</a>) within the SSC algorithm basically solves the OP&nbsp;(<a href="#M0027">15</a>) with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0142.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0142.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        ϵ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mn>
       0
      </mn>
     </math></span>: From convergence to <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0143.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0143.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mtext mathvariant="bold">
          l
         </mtext>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          b
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
        <mo>
         ,
        </mo>
        <mi>
         k
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         0
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow><mtext>
       &nbsp;
      </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">
       ∀
      </mi><mtext>
       &nbsp;
      </mtext><mi>
       k
      </mi><mo>
       ∈
      </mo><mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         K
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> follows that the computed solution satisfies <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0144.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0144.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mtext mathvariant="bold">
          g
         </mtext>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          b
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
        <mo>
         ,
        </mo>
        <mi>
         k
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         0
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow><mo>
       =
      </mo><msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mtext mathvariant="bold">
          h
         </mtext>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          b
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
        <mo>
         ,
        </mo>
        <mi>
         k
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mtext>
       &nbsp;
      </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">
       ∀
      </mi><mtext>
       &nbsp;
      </mtext><mi>
       k
      </mi><mo>
       ∈
      </mo><mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         K
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> and the augmented objective term vanishes. The remaining constraints of problems&nbsp;(<a href="#M0027">15</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0045">22</a>) are identical. Thus, the SSC algorithm computes a solution that is arbitrarily close, but not necessarily identical, to the solution of the piecewise linearly approximated problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0027">15</a>). The potential discrepancy in solutions is rooted in the necessity to smoothen the problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0027">15</a>) with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0145.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0145.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        ϵ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       &gt;
      </mo><mn>
       0
      </mn>
     </math></span> for the admissibility of the optimality conditions in&nbsp;Theorem&nbsp;2.1. Since the linearisation removes the discontinuity, the smoothing is disregarded within the SSC algorithm. From a practical standpoint, the discrepancy is negligible since the smoothing parameter can be assumed arbitrarily small&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0146.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0146.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        ϵ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       →
      </mo><mn>
       0
      </mn>
     </math></span> making the impact of the smoothing numerically irrelevant. This procedure for the approximation of discontinuities in optimal control problems is common practice, see e.g. (Perantoni &amp;&nbsp;Limebeer,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0041" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2014</a></span>). In summary, the SSC approach chooses one branch of the discontinuity, resulting in the continuously differentiable problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0045">22</a>) with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0147.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0147.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        ϵ
       </mi>
       <mi>
        s
       </mi>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mn>
       0
      </mn>
     </math></span>, and switches in the following iterations to the other branch if the wrong side of the discontinuity was selected.</p>
  </div>
 </div>
 <div id="S002-S2003" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i76">2.3. Constraint convexification via space splitting</h3>
  <p>The previous sections derived the basic structure of the convex OP&nbsp;(<a href="#M0045">22a</a>), which is solved in an iterative manner. However, the question of how the original constraints can be convexified via space splitting to gain the convex constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0028">15b</a>)–(<a href="#M0031">15e</a>) is still open. The basic procedure of bisecting the space of a variable into two subdomains has been illustrated in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2002-S3001">2.2.1</a>. This can be employed to consider ZCSs and equality constraints with univariate nonlinearities in a convex manner, which is demonstrated in Sections&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2003-S3001">2.3.1</a> and&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2003-S3002">2.3.2</a>, respectively. Subsequently, the index for the collocation discretisation&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0148.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0148.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mi>
      k
     </mi><mo>
      ∈
     </mo><mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mi>
        K
       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </mrow>
    </math></span> is omitted for readability.</p>
  <div id="S002-S2003-S3001" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3">
   <h4 class="section-heading-4" id="_i77">2.3.1. Convexification of zonally convex sets</h4>
   <p>One prominent physical example of ZCSs are constraints ensuring semi-activity. Semi-active actuators like limited slip differentials and semi-active dampers are used in many engineering applications due to their good compromise between low energy consumption and high performance&nbsp;(Savaresi et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0044" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2010</a></span>; Sedlacek et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0046" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020a</a></span>,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0048" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020c</a></span>). A typical ZCS for a semi-active damper is depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0004">4</a>(a) with damper force&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0149.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0149.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        F
       </mi>
       <mi>
        d
       </mi>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mi>
       u
      </mi>
     </math></span> and damper velocity&nbsp;<i>v</i>. The nonconvexity of the set is apparent considering that it is easy to draw a line that contains non-admissible points and connects an admissible point in the first quadrant with an admissible point in the third quadrant. Note that simply linearising the inequality constraints depicting this nonconvex set results in a half-plane, which represents a poor approximation of the set. The main idea for the novel convexification approach is appropriately decomposing nonconvex sets, described in the original decision variables, into convex subsets using auxiliary decision variables. The applicability of the SSC method to the ZCS types depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0004">4</a> is proven in the subsequent paragraphs.</p>
   <div class="figure figureViewer" id="F0004">
    <div class="hidden figureViewerArticleInfo">
     <span class="figViewerTitle">Space splitting convexification: a local solution method for nonconvex optimal control problems</span>
     <div class="articleAuthors articleInfoSection">
      <div class="authorsHeading">

Therein <i>v</i> and <i>u</i> are original decision variables. Moreover, <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0150.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0150.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mover>
         <mrow>
          <mrow>
           <mtext mathvariant="bold">
            h
           </mtext>
          </mrow>
         </mrow>
         <mo>
          ˆ
         </mo>
        </mover>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          z
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          c
         </mi>

          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
        <mo>
         ,
        </mo>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       ≤
      </mo><mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         0
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0151.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0151.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mover>
         <mrow>
          <mrow>
           <mtext mathvariant="bold">
            h
           </mtext>
          </mrow>
         </mrow>
         <mo>
          ˆ

       </mrow>

        <mi>
         n
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       ≤
      </mo><mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         0
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> are convex sets. The union of convex sets does not necessarily result in a convex set. As illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0004">4</a>(a), the union&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0152.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0152.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         S
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow><mo>
       =
      </mo><msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          S
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       ∪
      </mo><msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          S
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         n
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> is assumed to be nonconvex in this article. Thus, <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0153.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0153.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         S
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> is a nonconvex set comprised of convex subsets: a ZCS. The velocity&nbsp;<i>v</i> is split at <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0154.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0154.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mi>
        v
       </mi>
       <mo>
        =
       </mo>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
       <mo>
        =
       </mo>
       <mn>
        0
       </mn>
      </mrow>

   <p>Introducing analogous constraints to&nbsp;(<a href="#M0016">9a</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0020">11a</a>) as well as additional objective terms in form of&nbsp;(<a href="#M0022">11c</a>) ensures the relations in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0062">30</a>).      <noscript>

       =

      </mn>
     </math></span>. However, the common point of the subsets is not required to lie on the abscissa or ordinate. The vector of auxiliary decision variables is given by <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     <math>
      <mrow>
       <msub>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mtext mathvariant="bold">
           w
          </mtext>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           a

           u
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">

       </msub>
       <mo>

       </mo>

     </math></span>. While the original state variable&nbsp;<i>v</i> remains a decision variable in the problem, the input variable is replaced according to the transformation <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0063" class="disp-formula-label">(31) </span></span></span></span>which is affine in the decision variables. The convex subsets in terms of the auxiliary decision variables are given by <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0064.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0064.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0064" class="disp-formula-label">(32a) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
       <mtr>
        <mtd>
         <msub>
          <mrow>
           <mover>
            <mrow>
             <mrow>
              <mrow>
               <mi>
                S
               </mi>
              </mrow>
             </mrow>
            </mrow>
            <mo>
             ˆ
            </mo>
           </mover>
          </mrow>
          <mrow>
           <mi>
            p
           </mi>
          </mrow>
         </msub>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0065" class="disp-formula-label">(32b) </span></span></span></span>Hence, the convex subsets <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

       </mrow>
       <mrow>

       </mrow>

     </math></span> are now defined for separate decision variables and will be linked via the affine mapping&nbsp;(<a href="#M0063">31</a>). This enables the formulation of convex constraints as depicted in problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0027">15</a>). The proof that this procedure produces the same set as&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0164.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0164.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         S
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </math></span> will be given in Theorem&nbsp;2.3.</p>
   <p>For convexity, <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

           </mrow>
           <mo>
            ,
           </mo>
           <mi>
            n
           </mi>
          </mrow>
         </msub>
         <mo>
          (
         </mo>
         <mi>
          u
         </mi>
         <mo>
          ,
         </mo>
         <mi>
          v
         </mi>
         <mo>
          )
         </mo>
         <msub>
          <mrow>
           <mrow>
            <mtext mathvariant="bold">
             A
            </mtext>
           </mrow>
          </mrow>
          <mrow>
           <mrow>

           </mo>

           </mi>
          </mrow>
         </msub>
         <mfenced open="[" close="]">
          <mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em">
           <mtr>
            <mtd>
             <mi>

             </mi>
            </mtd>
           </mtr>
           <mtr>

             <mi>

          </mtable>
         </mfenced>
         <mo>

         </mo>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0067" class="disp-formula-label">(33b) </span></span></span></span>with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0171.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">

       <mrow>

         </mrow>
        </msub>
       </mrow>
      </msup>
     </math></span>.&nbsp;These constraints represent&nbsp;(<a href="#M0031">15e</a>) in the convex OP. Although nonlinear, convex functions for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0172.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0172.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mover>
         <mrow>
          <mrow>
           <mtext mathvariant="bold">
            h
           </mtext>
          </mrow>
         </mrow>
         <mo>
          ˆ
         </mo>
        </mover>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          z
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          c
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
        <mo>
         ,
        </mo>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0173.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0173.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mover>
         <mrow>
          <mrow>
           <mtext mathvariant="bold">
            h
           </mtext>
          </mrow>
         </mrow>

          ˆ
         </mo>

       </mrow>
       <mrow>

        <mi>

       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> would not prevent convexity, introducing such constraints would prohibit an LP or QP problem, which can be solved especially efficiently. Asymmetric subsets like the one illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0004">4</a>(a) can be easily implemented by using varying coefficients in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0066">33a</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0067">33b</a>) or by using different domains for&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0174.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0174.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          U
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mi>
        n
       </mi>
      </msub>
     </math></span> and&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0175.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0175.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          U
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mi>
        p
       </mi>
      </msub>
     </math></span>.</p><statement id="st10" content-type="theorem">
    Theorem 2.3 
    <p>The subsets&nbsp;(<a href="#M0064">32a</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0065">32b</a>) in combination with the affine mapping&nbsp;(<a href="#M0063">31</a>) depict the set <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0176.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0176.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          S
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </math></span> which is given by the union of the convex subsets&nbsp;(<a href="#M0060">29a</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0061">29b</a>).</p>
   </statement><statement id="st11" content-type="proof">
    Proof. 
    <p>For proving that the splitting approach provides sets that depict the original one, the individual cases for the bisected variable space are considered subsequently.</p>
    <p><b>Case 1</b>: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0177.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0177.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        &lt;
       </mo><mi>
        v
       </mi>
      </math></span></p>
    <p>The decision variable&nbsp;<i>v</i> is split at <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0178.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0178.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        v
       </mi><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span>. Thus, <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0179.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0179.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          n
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span> holds according to Lemma&nbsp;2.1. This concludes <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0180.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0180.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          n
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span> since the subsets converge to the common point <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0181.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0181.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mo>
        (
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        ,
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        )
       </mo>
      </math></span> when leaving the subset towards the other subset. Lemma&nbsp;2.1 also concludes <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0182.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0182.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          p
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><mi>
        v
       </mi>
      </math></span>. Then, the affine mapping&nbsp;(<a href="#M0063">31</a>) is given by <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0183.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0183.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         Φ
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          u
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          p
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        ∈
       </mo><msub>
        <mrow>
         <mover>
          <mrow>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mi>
              S
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
          </mrow>
          <mo>
           ˆ
          </mo>
         </mover>
        </mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          p
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span>. For <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0184.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0184.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        v
       </mi><mo>
        &gt;
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span>, <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0185.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0185.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          S
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi>
           S
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </msub>
      </math></span> holds. Since <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0186.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0186.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><mi>
        v
       </mi>
      </math></span>, <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0187.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0187.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        u
       </mi><mo>
        ∈
       </mo><msub>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi>
           S
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </msub>
      </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0188.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0188.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         Φ
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          u
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        ∈
       </mo><msub>
        <mrow>
         <mover>
          <mrow>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mi>
              S
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
          </mrow>
          <mo>
           ˆ
          </mo>
         </mover>
        </mrow>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </msub>
      </math></span> provide the same feasible set. The chain of conclusions for the remaining cases follows the same reasoning but is given below in equations for conciseness.</p>
    <p><b>Case 2</b>: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0189.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0189.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        v
       </mi><mo>
        &lt;
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span> <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0068.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0068.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0068" class="disp-formula-label">(34a) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

         <mtd>
          <mfenced open close="}">
           <mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em">

      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0068" class="disp-formula-label">(34a) </span></span></span></span><b>Case 3</b>: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0190.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0190.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        v
       </mi><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span> <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0069.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0069.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0069" class="disp-formula-label">(34b) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
        <mtr>
         <mtd>
          <mfenced open close="}">
           <mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em">
            <mtr>
             <mtd>
              <msub>
               <mi>

               </mi>
               <mrow>
                <mi>

                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>

              </mo>
              <msub>

           </mtable>
          </mfenced>
          <mo>

          </mo>
          <msub>
           <mi mathvariant="normal">
            Φ
           </mi>
           <mrow>
            <mi>
             u
            </mi>
           </mrow>
          </msub>
          <mo>

          </mo>
          <msub>
           <mi>
            u
           </mi>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mi mathvariant="normal">
              t
             </mi>
             <mi mathvariant="normal">
              r
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
          </msub>
          <mspace width="1em"></mspace>
          <mrow>
           <mover>
            <mo>
             =
            </mo>
            <mo>
             ˆ
            </mo>
           </mover>
          </mrow>
          <mspace width="1em"></mspace>
          <mi>
           u
          </mi>
          <mo>
           =
          </mo>
          <msub>
           <mi>
            u
           </mi>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mi mathvariant="normal">
              t
             </mi>
             <mi mathvariant="normal">
              r
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
          </msub>
          <mo>
           .
          </mo>
         </mtd>
        </mtr>
       </mtable>
      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0069" class="disp-formula-label">(34b) </span></span></span></span></p>
    <p>Thus, inserting the affine mapping&nbsp;(<a href="#M0063">31</a>) into the constraints while replacing the original set&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0191.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0191.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          S
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </math></span> with the sets&nbsp;(<a href="#M0064">32a</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0065">32b</a>) yields the same feasible set.</p>
   </statement>
   <p>The presented proof requires a space splitting of the variable&nbsp;<i>v</i> which is represented by splitting the convex subsets via a vertical line. Thus, the SSC approach is capable of convexifying two-dimensional ZCSs, which can be divided into two convex subsets connected in a single point using any vertical line. Following theorem is added to show that this also holds for any splitting line which is straight but possibly rotated:</p><statement id="st12" content-type="theorem">
    Theorem 2.4 
    <p>Space splitting applied to a rotated, two-dimensional ZCS also results in convex constraints.</p>
   </statement><statement id="st13" content-type="proof">
    Proof. 
    <p>This can be verified by applying the previously described procedure to a rotated coordinate frame, exemplarily depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0004">4</a>(b). The auxiliary decision variables need to split the rotated two-dimensional space spanned by the variables <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0192.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0192.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="script">
         v
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0193.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0193.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="script">
         u
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </math></span>. Assuming the coordinate system is rotated by the angle&nbsp;<i>φ</i> with counter-clockwise rotations depicting positive rotations, following relations hold between the original coordinates <i>v</i>−<i>u</i> and the rotated coordinates <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0194.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="script">
         v
        </mi>
       </mrow><mo>
        −
       </mo><mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="script">
         u
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </math></span>: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

       </mo>
      </math></span>. However, an adjustment using&nbsp;(<a href="#M0070">35</a>) is necessary for the constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0016">9a</a>),&nbsp;(<a href="#M0020">11a</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0021">11b</a>) as well as the input mapping&nbsp;(<a href="#M0063">31</a>): <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

       </mtable>
      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0074" class="disp-formula-label">(36d) </span></span></span></span>Since the angle <i>φ</i> is constant, the trigonometric functions represent constant values. Thus, a rotated space splitting procedure also yields affine constraints and mappings enabling the formulation of a convex OP.</p>
   </statement>
   <p>The previous theorems required the subsets to be connected in a single point. Following theorem states that the SSC approach can be used to approximate ZCSs which share a line of points:</p><statement id="st14" content-type="theorem">
    Theorem 2.5 
    <p>When a two-dimensional ZCSs is comprised of two convex subsets sharing a line of points, the SSC approach can only approximate the original set however with sufficiently small approximation error.</p>
   </statement><statement id="st15" content-type="proof">
    Proof. 
    <p>Without loss of generality, this can be analysed considering Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0004">4</a>(c) as example. For the depicted case, the transition line lies on the ordinate&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0200.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0200.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><mn>
        0
       </mn>
      </math></span>. Analysing the individual cases shows that using the original subsets within the SSC approach would yield a larger set than the original set:</p>
    <p><b>Case 1</b>: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0201.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0201.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        &lt;
       </mo><mi>
        v
       </mi>
      </math></span> <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0075.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0075.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0075" class="disp-formula-label">(37a) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
        <mtr>
         <mtd>
          <mfenced open close="}">
           <mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em">
            <mtr>
             <mtd>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                v
               </mi>
               <mrow>
                <mi>
                 p
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>
               =
              </mo>
              <mi>
               v
              </mi>
              <mo>
               ⇒
              </mo>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                u
               </mi>
               <mrow>
                <mi>
                 p
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>
               ∈
              </mo>
              <msub>
               <mrow>
                <mover>
                 <mrow>
                  <mrow>
                   <mrow>
                    <mi>
                     S
                    </mi>
                   </mrow>
                  </mrow>
                 </mrow>
                 <mo>
                  ˆ
                 </mo>
                </mover>
               </mrow>
               <mi>
                p
               </mi>
              </msub>
             </mtd>
            </mtr>
            <mtr>
             <mtd>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                v
               </mi>
               <mrow>
                <mi>
                 n
                </mi>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>
               =
              </mo>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                v
               </mi>
               <mrow>
                <mrow>
                 <mi mathvariant="normal">
                  t
                 </mi>
                 <mi mathvariant="normal">
                  r
                 </mi>
                </mrow>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>

              </mo>

               </mi>

    <p>Thus, using the original subsets can render non-admissible points of the original problem admissible. When the input variable is replaced by the auxiliary inputs according to&nbsp;(<a href="#M0063">31</a>), both sets must be adjusted at the transition line <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0204.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0204.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        v
       </mi><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         v
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span>. The simplest set adjustment is enforcing <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0205.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0205.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
        <mi>
         n
        </mi>
       </msub><mo>
        =
       </mo><mn>
        0
       </mn><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
        <mi>
         p
        </mi>
       </msub>
      </math></span> at the transition axis, as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0004">4c</a> by the dotted lines. Then, the subsets are connected in a single point enabling the application of Theorem&nbsp;2.4. However, other set manipulations are possible and can be numerically better. Generally, such set approximations introduce conservativeness for the sake of feasible trajectories. However, the introduced error is negligible when the removed area is sufficiently small which can be implemented by choosing steep linear constraints at the transition between the subsets.</p>
   </statement><statement id="st16" content-type="remark">
    Remark 2.2 
    <p>In this article, only two-dimensional ZCSs which can be split into two convex subsets have been considered. However, the SSC approach can be applied to certain two-dimensional ZCSs with more than two subsets. For instance, consider three convex subsets positioned horizontally to each other, whereas each subset is connected to the next subset in a single point on the abscissa. This can be verified using the procedures described previously in this section.</p>
   </statement>
   <p>This section illustrated the convexification procedure for ZCSs in regards to inputs. This results in the depicted affine input transformation&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0206.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0206.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        Φ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         u
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span>. Implementing the approach for a ZCS with state decision variables yields an affine transformation&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        Φ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         x
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span>. This procedure can be applied to multiple inputs and states. The corresponding vector functions for the affine transformations are given by <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
