  </div>
  <div id="S002-S2003-S3002" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3">
   <h4 class="section-heading-4" id="_i98">2.3.2. Convexification of nonlinear equality constraints</h4>
   <p>Some nonlinearities in physical systems are characterised by a univariate function. Examples are nonlinear springs, saturation, dead-zones or the tire force shape curve of vehicles. Since nonlinear system equations yield nonlinear thus nonconvex equality constraints, this section presents how such nonlinear univariate terms can be convexified. The nonlinear univariate curve is depicted using piecewise affine parts. Hence, if the nonlinearity is not a piecewise linear function, SSC introduces approximation errors. The subsequent paragraphs illustrate the application of the SSC algorithm for convexifying piecewise linear nonlinearities. <statement id="st17" content-type="theorem">
     Theorem 2.6 
    </statement></p>
   <p>The splitting constraints in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0016">9</a>) can be used to convexify equality constraints by transforming a univariate nonlinearity with two piecewise linear segments into an expression which is affine in multiple decision variables.</p> <statement id="st18" content-type="proof">
    Proof. 
    <p>Proof is provided using the piecewise linear curve depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0005">5</a>(a) as example, which represents a typical function for piecewise linear springs. Assuming the position&nbsp;<i>x</i> is a state of the system, it represents a decision variable which will be split at the transition point&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0213.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0213.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        x
       </mi><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mi>
         x
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           r
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub><mo>
        &lt;
       </mo><mn>
        0
       </mn>
      </math></span>. Thus, the auxiliary position variables <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0214.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0214.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>

      <math>
       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

            <mtr>

              <mi>
               x
              </mi>
             </mtd>
             <mtd>
              <mi mathvariant="normal">
               ∀
              </mi>
              <mtext>
               &nbsp;
              </mtext>
              <mi>
               x
              </mi>
              <mo>

              </mo>
              <msub>
               <mi>
                x
               </mi>
               <mrow>

                </mrow>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
              <mo>

              </mo>
             </mtd>
            </mtr>
            <mtr>
             <mtd>
              <msub>
               <mi>

                </mrow>
               </mrow>
              </msub>
             </mtd>
             <mtd>
              <mrow>
               <mi mathvariant="normal">

               <mi mathvariant="normal">

              </mrow>

          </mfenced>
          <mo>

          </mo>
         </mtd>
        </mtr>
       </mtable>
      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0079" class="disp-formula-label">(39) </span></span></span></span>Hence, the piecewise linear function can be represented by the expression <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0080.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0080" class="disp-formula-label">(40) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0080" class="disp-formula-label">(40) </span></span></span></span>which is affine in the decision variables&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0216.gif" alt="">

      <math>
       <msub>
        <mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mtext mathvariant="bold">
           w
          </mtext>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>

         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span>. The relations in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0079">39</a>) yield following two segments for the piecewise linear function&nbsp;(<a href="#M0080">40</a>): <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

      <math>
       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0081" class="disp-formula-label">(41a) </span></span></span></span> <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

       <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

           </mrow>
          </msub>
          <mo>

          </mo>

          </mi>
          <mo>
           −
          </mo>
          <msub>
           <mi>
            x
           </mi>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mi mathvariant="normal">
              t
             </mi>
             <mi mathvariant="normal">
              r
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
          </msub>
          <mo>

          </mo>
          <mo>

          </mo>
         </mtd>
        </mtr>
       </mtable>
      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0082" class="disp-formula-label">(41b) </span></span></span></span>Thus,&nbsp;(<a href="#M0081">41a</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0082">41b</a>) depict the upper and lower segment of the nonlinearity, respectively.</p>
   </statement>
   <p></p>
   <p>Since&nbsp;(<a href="#M0080">40</a>) is an affine function in the decision variables, it can be inserted into the differential equations without preventing convexity. The subsequent theorem proves that this approach can be extended to univariate nonlinearities with more than two piecewise linear segments:</p>
   <div class="figure figureViewer" id="F0005">
    <div class="hidden figureViewerArticleInfo">
     <span class="figViewerTitle">Space splitting convexification: a local solution method for nonconvex optimal control problems</span>
     <div class="articleAuthors articleInfoSection">
      <div class="authorsHeading">
       All authors
      </div>

   <p></p><statement id="st19" content-type="theorem">
    Theorem 2.7 
    <p>A repeated application of the space bisection approach using the splitting constraints in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0016">9</a>) can be used to convexify equality constraints by transforming a univariate nonlinearity with more than two piecewise linear segments into an expression which is affine in multiple decision variables.</p>
   </statement><statement id="st20" content-type="proof">
    Proof. 
    <p>The general procedure for this extension is illustrated using the piecewise linear curve depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0005">5</a>(b). The position <i>x</i> is split at the transition points <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0217.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0217.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>

        0
       </mn>
      </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0084" class="disp-formula-label">(42b) </span></span></span></span>which is depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0005">5</a>. Thus, the position space is bisected into a region below and a region above&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0223.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0223.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mrow>
        <mi>
         x
        </mi>
        <mo>
         =
        </mo>
        <msub>
         <munder>
          <mi>
           x
          </mi>
          <mo>
           _
          </mo>
         </munder>
         <mrow>
          <mrow>

           </mi>
           <mi mathvariant="normal">
            r
           </mi>
          </mrow>
         </mrow>
        </msub>
       </mrow>
      </math></span> whereas the upper region is again bisected into a region below and above&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
      <noscript>
       <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0224.gif" alt="">
      </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0224.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
      <math>
       <mi>
        x
       </mi><mo>
        =
       </mo><msub>
        <mover>
         <mi>
          x
         </mi>
         <mo accent="false">
          ¯
         </mo>
        </mover>
        <mrow>

          <mi mathvariant="normal">

          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">

          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </math></span>. The piecewise linear function can then be represented by the expression <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

      </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0088" class="disp-formula-label">(44c) </span></span></span></span>Hence,&nbsp;(<a href="#M0086">44a</a>),&nbsp;(<a href="#M0087">44b</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0088">44c</a>) depict the upper, mid and lower segment of the nonlinearity, respectively.</p>
   </statement>
   <p>This repeated bisection procedure enables the generation of a characteristic curve with an arbitrary number of segments. However, an increasing number of segments also increases the number of auxiliary decision variables and additional constraints making the OP larger.</p>
   <p>The approach presented in this section yields a scalar function&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0226.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0226.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        Φ
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          p
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          w
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          l
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> which is affine in the decision variables. The procedure can be applied to multiple univariate, nonlinear terms yielding further scalar mapping functions. The affine vector-valued function in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0034">16</a>) is given by <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

  </div>
 </div>
 <div id="S002-S2004" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i111">2.4. Remarks on runtime</h3>
  <p>The application of optimisation methods within a real-time capable controller generally requires upper bounds on the necessary computation time. The SSC approach runs through a loop which is comprised of a projection step and an optimisation step resulting in the following theorem regarding computational complexity:</p><statement id="st21" content-type="theorem">
   Theorem 2.8 
   <p>The computational complexity of the SSC algorithm is polynomial.</p>
  </statement><statement id="st22" content-type="proof">
   Proof. 
   <p>SSC solves a sequence of LP problems or convex QP problems, which are known to be solvable in polynomial time&nbsp;(Karmarkar,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0021" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1984</a></span>; Kozlov et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0025" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1980</a></span>). The projection step&nbsp;(<a href="#M0023">12</a>) of the SSC algorithm uses minimum and maximum functions which possess linear time complexity. This concludes a polynomial time complexity of the SSC algorithm: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0090.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0090.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0090" class="disp-formula-label">(46) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
       <mtr>
        <mtd>
         <msub>
          <mi>
           T
          </mi>
          <mrow>
           <mrow>
            <mi mathvariant="normal">
             S
            </mi>
            <mi mathvariant="normal">
             S
            </mi>
            <mi mathvariant="normal">
             C
            </mi>
           </mrow>
          </mrow>
         </msub>
         <mo>
          (
         </mo>
         <mi>
          n
         </mi>
         <mo>
          ,
         </mo>
         <mi>
          q
         </mi>
         <mo>
          )
         </mo>
         <mo>
          =
         </mo>
         <mi>
          q
         </mi>
         <mo>
          ⋅
         </mo>
         <mfenced open="(" close=")">
          <mrow>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mi>
              O
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
           <mo>
            (
           </mo>
           <msup>
            <mi>
             n
            </mi>
            <mrow>
             <mi>
              α
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </msup>
           <mo>
            )
           </mo>
           <mo>
            +
           </mo>
           <mi>
            c
           </mi>
           <mrow>
            <mrow>
             <mi>
              O
             </mi>
            </mrow>
           </mrow>
           <mo>
            (
           </mo>
           <mi>
            n
           </mi>
           <mo>
            )
           </mo>
          </mrow>
         </mfenced>
         <mspace width="1em"></mspace>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           w
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           i
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           t
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           h
          </mi>
         </mrow>
         <mtext>
          &nbsp;
         </mtext>
         <mi>
          α
         </mi>
         <mo>
          &gt;
         </mo>
         <mn>
          1.
         </mn>
        </mtd>
       </mtr>
      </mtable>
     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0090" class="disp-formula-label">(46) </span></span></span></span>Therein <i>n</i> can be interpreted as the number of operations required by the algorithm. The parameters in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0090">46</a>) depend on the utilised solver as well as the number of decision variables which is problem specific. Limiting the maximum number of superordinate iterations to <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0229.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0229.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mi>
       q
      </mi><mo>
       ≤
      </mo><msub>
       <mi>
        q
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          m
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          x
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
     </math></span> enables terminating the algorithm prematurely at suboptimal solutions, if necessary.</p>
  </statement>
  <p>Theorem&nbsp;2.8 provides valuable insight for the application in a real-time capable controller. Firstly, a worst-case bound on computation time can be experimentally identified for the specific OP and solver. Secondly, the computation time scales well with increasing problem size. Since the number of superordinate SSC iterations is rather low in practice, this results in a fast solution of optimal control problems. Finally, the influences on computation time are summarised below:</p>
  <ol class="NLM_list NLM_list-list_type-order">
   <li><p class="inline"><i>System and discretisation.</i> The number of decision variables increases with rising number of inputs, states and collocation segments for both the original and the convexified OP. This increases computation time for NLP methods and the SSC algorithm. Due to the polynomial complexity, this increase in time will be generally less for SSC than for NLP.</p></li>
   <li><p class="inline"><i>Nonlinearity.</i> The more complicated the nonlinearity, the more splitting segments are required to reduce approximation errors. However, the space splitting increases the problem size compared to the original problem, which influences the variable&nbsp;<i>n</i> in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0090">46</a>). This can put a practical bound on the number of space divisions via the SSC approach. Nevertheless, many physically motivated nonlinearities can be approximated sufficiently well using a moderate number of affine segments.</p></li>
   <li><p class="inline"><i>Initial guess.</i> Being a local method, the solution computed by the SSC approach depends on the provided initial solution. Furthermore, this initial guess can influence the order of sign-corrections regarding the AVC-linearisations, which can impact the number of superordinate iterations and, therefore, the convergence rate. For MPC frameworks, the optimal solution of the preceding time step often represents a good initial guess&nbsp;(Gros et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0018" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020</a></span>) promising low computation times.</p></li>
   <li><p class="inline"><i>Penalty parameter update.</i> Too small or too large penalty parameters can slow down convergence (Nocedal &amp; Wright,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0039" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2006</a></span>, p.&nbsp;511). The straightforward approach of gradually increasing the penalty parameter is used in this article. However, more sophisticated routines have been proposed in&nbsp;Mayne and&nbsp;Maratos&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0036" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1979</a></span>) and Maratos&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0034" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1978</a></span>).</p></li>
  </ol>
  <p></p>
 </div>
 <div id="S002-S2005" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i113">2.5. Comparison with existing methods</h3>
  <p>In order to highlight the novelty of the proposed algorithm, this section compares the SSC approach with the most related existing methods.</p>
  <p>From an algorithmic standpoint, linearising only the nonconvex part of constraints combined with a relaxation and an increasing objective term penalising constraint violations corresponds to penalty&nbsp;CCP&nbsp;(Lipp &amp;&nbsp;Boyd,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0030" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2016</a></span>). CCP has the advantage over SQP and other linearisation techniques that it retains more problem information in each iterate: The information of the convex parts is kept and only the concave portions are linearised. Furthermore, CCP does not require to use line-search procedures or limit the progress in each iteration via trust-region methods. Inspired by&nbsp;Mangasarian&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0031" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2015</a></span>), the SSC approach avoids additional slack variables by considering the linearised constraints directly in the penalty objective. This avoids further increasing the size of the OP as in penalty&nbsp;CCP. Moreover, SSC employs an intermediate projection to enhance convergence. While CCP linearises the concave part of all nonconvexities, SSC transforms the problem beforehand requiring only the linearisation of AVCs. This enables providing a feedback about the correctness of the selected linearisation points, which are subsequently adjusted. Thus, the linearisation error can vanish completely after the correct signs have been chosen. The binary nature of the linearisation facilitates a rapid convergence in a small number of superordinate iterations. Although the SSC method only computes solutions to the piecewise linear approximation of the original problem, the approximation can be designed to sufficient accuracy enabling small and known approximation errors. Especially the straightforward linearisation of ZCS-constraints yields very poor approximations, which can contain a large set of infeasible points. Thus, the vanishing AVC-linearisation errors result in an advantage of SSC regarding accuracy, also over further linearisation techniques like the ones presented in Mao et al.&nbsp;( <span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0033" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2016</a></span>, <span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0032" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>). Generally, a scalable trade-off between accuracy and size of the OP, thus computation time, can be chosen. Opposed to&nbsp;Lipp and&nbsp;Boyd&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0030" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2016</a></span>), this article provides a convergence proof, even if only converging to the solution of the approximated problem.</p>
  <p>While LC possesses the advantage of avoiding approximation errors, it is only applicable to OPs with annulus-like, nonconvex sets resulting from excluding a convex subset from a convex set&nbsp;(Raković &amp;&nbsp;Levine,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0042" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2018</a></span>, p.&nbsp;340). Opposed to that, SSC provides a method for the convexification of ZCS which cannot be considered via LC.</p>
  <p>Similar to the LnP approach presented in&nbsp;Mao et al.&nbsp;(<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0032" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>), the SSC method is an iterative linearisation algorithm using intermediate projection steps. The updating routine for SSC is of linear computational complexity with few and simple mathematical operations. The projection step of the LnP approach generally requires the solution of a convex programming problem, which is of polynomial complexity at best. Thus, the projection step used by the SSC approach is computationally less costly, which is beneficial for splitting methods&nbsp;(Ferreau et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0017" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>). Additionally, the binary nature of the AVC-linearisation provides the advantage that generally only few superordinate iterations are required, resulting in short computation times. Moreover, SSC is more robust regarding the initialisation since the&nbsp;LnP&nbsp;approach requires an additional lifting procedure to cope with arbitrary initialisations, which costs computation time&nbsp;(Mao et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0032" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>). Furthermore, the LnP method requires the right-hand side of the system equations to be convex and the inequality constraints to be concave. However, nonconvex collision avoidance constraints can be easily considered via the LnP approach, whereas the SSC procedure requires further measures.</p>
  <p>The ADMM is a splitting procedure utilising the augmented Lagrangian method instead of the exact penalty function method, which is employed by the SSC algorithm. Due to the alternating approach, the ADMM requires the solution of two QCQP problems in each iteration. The SSC approach only requires the solution of a single convex QP problem in each iteration, which is beneficial for computation time.</p>
  <p>The spatial BnB method also uses space decomposition for the convexification of the optimisation problem. However, the SSC approach solves a piecewise linear approximation of the original problem, which is iteratively adjusted, on the full space domain of the decision variables. Opposed to that, the BnB method solves multiple OPs which represent convexly relaxed versions of the original problem on separate subdomains of the decision variables. BnB techniques determine upper bounds by evaluating the objective function at a feasible point. Since the problem is generally nonconvex, finding a feasible point can be difficult. This is often tackled by solving the nonconvex subproblem locally, which is computationally expensive&nbsp;(Liberti &amp;&nbsp;Maculan,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0028" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2006</a></span>, p.&nbsp;253). Thus, the convergence rate of the SSC approach is most likely to be superior if sufficiently good initial guesses are provided. However, this depends on the nonlinearities of the OP, which influence the number of decision variables for SSC but also for BnB approaches which decompose factorable functions&nbsp;(Tawarmalani &amp;&nbsp;Sahinidis,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0054" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2002</a></span>, p.&nbsp;125). Moreover, SSC only guarantees to find local optima of an approximation of the OP and is only applicable to certain classes of OPs. GO techniques cover a wide range of applicability and provide the global optimum.</p>
 </div>
</div>
<div id="S003" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1">
 <h2 id="_i114" class="section-heading-2">3. Applications</h2>
 <p>In this section, the proposed SSC algorithm is evaluated using a hanging SMO example with piecewise linear spring and semi-active damping as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0006">6</a>. Semi-active dampers can only generate a force in the opposite moving direction and cannot impose a force at steady-state complying with the passivity constraint&nbsp;(Savaresi et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0044" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2010</a></span>, p.&nbsp;16). Hence, the admissible set for semi-active dampers always contains a subset in the first quadrant and a subset in the third quadrant which are connected in a single point, namely, the origin. A performance-oriented OP is formulated and solved using NLP and SSC, respectively. The results of both algorithms are compared regarding accuracy and computation time. Both problems are posed using the modelling language <i>JuMP</i>&nbsp;(Dunning et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0014" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>) for mathematical OPs. For a fair comparison, the necessary derivatives are computed beforehand via automatic differentiation. Furthermore, the tolerances for constraint feasibility and objective improvement are set to <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
   <noscript>
    <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0230.gif" alt="">
   </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0230.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
   <math>
    <msup>
     <mn>
      10
     </mn>
     <mrow>
      <mo>
       −
      </mo>
      <mn>
       6
      </mn>
     </mrow>
    </msup>
   </math></span> for both solvers. The utilised parameters are listed with description in Table&nbsp;<button class="ref showTableEventRef" data-id="T0001">1</button>.</p>

  <div class="figureFootNote-F0006"></div>

 <div class="tableViewerArticleInfo hidden">
  <span class="figViewerTitle">Space splitting convexification: a local solution method for nonconvex optimal control problems</span>
  <div class="articleAuthors articleInfoSection">
   <div class="authorsHeading">
    All authors
   </div>
   <div class="authors">
    <a class="entryAuthor" href="/action/doSearch?Contrib=Sedlacek%2C+Tadeas"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor"></span></a><a href="/author/Sedlacek%2C+Tadeas"><span class="NLM_given-names">Tadeas</span> Sedlacek</a> <a href="https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6191-6173"><img src="/templates/jsp/images/orcid.png"></a>, <a class="entryAuthor" href="/action/doSearch?Contrib=Odenthal%2C+Dirk"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor"></span></a><a href="/author/Odenthal%2C+Dirk"><span class="NLM_given-names">Dirk</span> Odenthal</a> <a href="https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6651-8369"><img src="/templates/jsp/images/orcid.png"></a> &amp; <a class="entryAuthor" href="/action/doSearch?Contrib=Wollherr%2C+Dirk"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor"></span></a><a href="/author/Wollherr%2C+Dirk"><span class="NLM_given-names">Dirk</span> Wollherr</a> <a href="https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2810-6790"><img src="/templates/jsp/images/orcid.png"></a>
   </div>
  </div>
  <div class="articleLowerInfo articleInfoSection">
   <div class="articleLowerInfoSection articleInfoDOI">
    <a href="https://doi.org/10.1080/00207179.2021.2004449">https://doi.org/10.1080/00207179.2021.2004449</a>
   </div>
   <div class="articleInfoPublicationDate articleLowerInfoSection border">
    <h6>Published online:</h6>25 November 2021
   </div>
  </div>
 </div>
 <div class="tableView">
  <div class="tableCaption">
   <div class="short-legend">
    <h3><p class="captionText"><span class="captionLabel">Table 1. </span> Parameters for SMO application.</p></h3>
   </div>
  </div>
  <div class="tableDownloadOption" data-hascsvlnk="false" id="T0001-table-wrapper">
   <a data-id="T0001" class="downloadButton btn btn-sm displaySizeTable" href="#" role="button">Display Table</a>
  </div>
 </div>
 <p></p>
 <p>The NLP problem is solved using the optimiser <i>IPOPT</i>(Wächter &amp;&nbsp;Biegler,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0056" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2006</a></span>), which employs an interior-point method: Using the concept of barrier functions, a sequence of relaxed problems is solved for decreasing values of barrier parameters. The barrier parameter relaxes the inequality constraints and hence represents the distance from the current iterate to the border of the admissible set. Thus, interior-point methods use a central path within the admissible set as opposed to SQP-methods which wander along the border. The resulting nonlinear equation system is solved via a damped Newton method. Furthermore, a filter line-search method, heuristics and further correction measures are employed to enhance convergence and robustness.</p>
 <p>The novel SSC method transforms the OP into convex QP subproblems which are solved iteratively. In order to capitalise on this problem structure, the elaborate optimiser <i>Gurobi</i>&nbsp;(Gurobi Optimization,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0019" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020</a></span>) is selected.</p>
 <div id="S003-S2001" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i116">3.1. Optimisation problems</h3>
  <p>The equations of motion for the state vector&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0255.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0255.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">

    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0256.gif" alt="">

    </math></span> denoting the deflection position, deflection speed, damper force and spring force, respectively. The expression of these forces differs for the NLP method and the SSC approach.     </math></span> while considering the limitations of the system. Applying Simpson quadrature&nbsp;(Betts,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0004" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2010</a></span>; Kelly,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0022" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>), the main objective penalises the steady-state position deviation&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

    </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0092" class="disp-formula-label">(48) </span></span></span></span>Considering the values listed in Table&nbsp;<button class="ref showTableEventRef" data-id="T0001">1</button>, the steady-state position can be computed using a root-finding approach like Newton's method: At steady-state position, the gravitational force must equal the spring force. For the considered nonlinear springs with two piecewise linear segments the value <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

       <mo>

       </mo>

      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> is chosen and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     </msubsup><mo>
      =
     </mo><mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mtext mathvariant="bold">
        0
       </mtext>
      </mrow>
     </mrow>
    </math></span>. From <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

    </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0093" class="disp-formula-label">(49) </span></span></span></span>follows that the Hessian of&nbsp;(<a href="#M0092">48</a>) is a diagonal matrix with only positive and zero diagonal entries and therefore positive semi-definite. Hence, the main objective&nbsp;(<a href="#M0092">48</a>) is a convex function.</p>
  <div id="S003-S2001-S3001" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3">
   <h4 class="section-heading-4" id="_i120">3.1.1. Nonlinear nonconvex optimisation problem</h4>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0100" class="disp-formula-label">(51e) </span></span></span></span>The nonconvex NLP problem&nbsp;(51) is comprised of following parts: objective function&nbsp;(<a href="#M0096">51a</a>), collocation constraints&nbsp;(51b), bounds for the decision variables&nbsp;(<a href="#M0098">51c</a>), damper force bounds&nbsp;(<a href="#M0099">51d</a>) and initial value condition&nbsp;(<a href="#M0100">51e</a>). The piecewise linear spring force is approximated in&nbsp;(51b) via the smoothed minimum-function <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0101.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0101.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0101" class="disp-formula-label">(52) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

        <mtd>
         <msub>
          <mrow>

           <mi mathvariant="normal">

           <mi mathvariant="normal">

           </mi>
          </mrow>

         </msub>
         <mo>

          ,

           </msqrt>
          </mrow>

      </mtable>
     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0101" class="disp-formula-label">(52) </span></span></span></span>using&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0270.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0270.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mi>
       ϵ
      </mi><mo>
       =
      </mo><msup>
       <mn>
        10
       </mn>
       <mrow>
        <mo>
         −
        </mo>
        <mn>
         16
        </mn>
       </mrow>
      </msup>
     </math></span> to guarantee that the problem is twice continuously differentiable&nbsp;(Sedlacek et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0047" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020b</a></span>). Problem&nbsp;(51) is nonconvex due to the right-hand side of the differential equation system in the collocation constraints&nbsp;(51b) and due to the damper force bounds&nbsp;(<a href="#M0099">51d</a>).</p>
  </div>
  <div id="S003-S2001-S3002" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3">
   <h4 class="section-heading-4" id="_i129">3.1.2. Convex QP-problem for iterative solution</h4>
   <p>Following the SSC approach, auxiliary optimisation variables are introduced, which results in the subsequent decision variables: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0102.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0102.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0102" class="disp-formula-label">(53a) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
       <mtr>
        <mtd>
         <mtable columnalign="right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em">
          <mtr>
           <mtd>
            <mrow>
             <mrow>
              <mtext mathvariant="bold">
               U
              </mtext>
             </mrow>
            </mrow>
           </mtd>
           <mtd>
            <mo>
             =
            </mo>
            <mfenced open="[" close="]">
             <mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em">
              <mtr>
               <mtd>
                <msub>
                 <mrow>
                  <mrow>
                   <mtext mathvariant="bold">
                    u
                   </mtext>
                  </mrow>
                 </mrow>
                 <mrow>
                  <mn>
                   0
                  </mn>
                 </mrow>
                </msub>
               </mtd>
               <mtd>
                <msub>
                 <mrow>
                  <mrow>
                   <mtext mathvariant="bold">
                    u
                   </mtext>
                  </mrow>
                 </mrow>
                 <mrow>

                   k
                  </mi>
                 </mrow>
                </msub>
               </mtd>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0105" class="disp-formula-label">(53d) </span></span></span></span>Opposed to the inputs&nbsp;(<a href="#M0094">50a</a>) of the NLP problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0096">51a</a>), the inputs in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0102">53a</a>) represent the positive and negative part of the damper force.</p>
   <p>As illustrated in Algorithm&nbsp;1, a projection routine is executed in each iteration. Based on the preceding solution marked by values&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0271.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0271.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mo>
       (
      </mo><mo>
       ⋅
      </mo><msup>
       <mo>
        )
       </mo>
       <mrow>

      </msup>

     <noscript>

     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0108.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0108" class="disp-formula-label">(54c) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

        <mtd>
         <msub>
          <mi>

          </mi>
          <mrow>
           <mi>
            x
           </mi>
           <mo>
            ,
           </mo>
           <mi>
            k
           </mi>
          </mrow>
         </msub>
         <mo>
          =
         </mo>
         <mrow>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           s
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           i
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           g
          </mi>
          <mi mathvariant="normal">
           n
          </mi>
         </mrow>
         <mo>

         </mo>

         </msubsup>
         <mo>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0108" class="disp-formula-label">(54c) </span></span></span></span>For a concise notation in the OP, the decision variables are lumped together in&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0116" class="disp-formula-label">(55h) </span></span></span></span>The QP problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55</a>) is comprised of following parts: augmented objective function&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55a</a>), collocation constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0111">55c</a>), bounds for the decision variables&nbsp;(<a href="#M0112">55d</a>), ZCS-constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0113">55e</a>), the additional space splitting constraints&nbsp;(<a href="#M0114">55f</a>)–(<a href="#M0115">55g</a>) and initial value condition&nbsp;(<a href="#M0116">55h</a>). Due to the splitting approach, the right-hand side of the differential equation system in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0111">55c</a>) is an affine function in the decision variables. Thus, all constraints are affine in the decision variables and therefore convex. The additional objectives with&nbsp;(<a href="#M0110">55b</a>) are affine in the decision variables representing convex functions. Hence,&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55</a>) represents a convex QP problem. Using&nbsp;(<a href="#M0110">55b</a>), the termination criterium in line&nbsp;9 of Algorithm&nbsp;1 is computed via <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0117.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0117.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0117" class="disp-formula-label">(56) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
     <math>
      <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
       <mtr>
        <mtd>
         <msub>
          <mover>
           <mi>
            l
           </mi>
           <mo accent="false">
            ¯
           </mo>
          </mover>
          <mrow>
           <mrow>
            <mi mathvariant="normal">
             a
            </mi>
            <mi mathvariant="normal">
             b
            </mi>
            <mi mathvariant="normal">
             s
            </mi>
           </mrow>
          </mrow>
         </msub>
         <mo>
          =
         </mo>
         <msub>
          <mrow>
           <mfenced open="∥" close="∥">
            <mrow>

     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0117" class="disp-formula-label">(56) </span></span></span></span>As illustrated in line&nbsp;6 of Algorithm&nbsp;1, the penalty weight <i>τ</i> is linearly increased with a maximum iteration number <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     <math>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        q
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">

         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          a
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">

         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub><mo>
       =
      </mo><mn>
       6
      </mn>
     </math></span> using the lower and upper bound <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>
      <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0280.gif" alt="">
     </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0280.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">

       </mo>
      </munder>
     </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
     <noscript>

     <math>
      <mover>
       <mi>

       <mo accent="false">
        ¯

     </math></span>, respectively. Both OPs are now fully defined. The results generated by solving NLP problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0096">51</a>) and by applying the SSC algorithm with QP problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55</a>) are compared in the following section.</p>
  </div>
 </div>
 <div id="S003-S2002" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i146">3.2. Results</h3>
  <p>In order to inspect the performance of the proposed SSC algorithm, 100 OPs are analysed in this section using a desktop computer with Intel Core<sup>TM</sup>&nbsp;i7-9850H CPU to determine the solutions. The OPs vary in size and the initial value condition. The number of collocation segments is gradually increased with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0282.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0282.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       n
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         e
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         g
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      ∈
     </mo><mo fence="false">
      {
     </mo><mn>
      10
     </mn><mo>
      ,
     </mo><mn>
      50
     </mn><mo>
      ,
     </mo><mn>
      100
     </mn><mo>
      ,
     </mo><mn>
      250
     </mn><mo>
      ,
     </mo><mn>
      500
     </mn><mo fence="false">
      }
     </mo>
    </math></span>. For each problem size, the OPs&nbsp;(<a href="#M0096">51</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55</a>) are solved using the 10 random, admissible initial values&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0283.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0283.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         x
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         v
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> listed in Table&nbsp;<button class="ref showTableEventRef" data-id="T0002">2</button>. This procedure is also executed for a simplified QP problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55</a>) with a fully linear spring of stiffness&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0284.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0284.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       c
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         m
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         d
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span>. This simplifies the right-hand side of the differential equation system in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0111">55c</a>) and eliminates the need for the auxiliary variables&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0285.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0285.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         X
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         a
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         u
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         x
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0104">53c</a>), the corresponding additional objectives in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0110">55b</a>) as well as the corresponding constraints in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0114">55f</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0115">55g</a>). The optimisation results are displayed in Table&nbsp;<button class="ref showTableEventRef" data-id="T0003">3</button>.</p>

  <p>Firstly, the OPs with initial value <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

     <msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">

       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>

        <mi mathvariant="normal">

     </mo><msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         x
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>

        <mi mathvariant="normal">

       </mrow>

       </mo>

       </mn>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0311.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0311.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       n
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">

        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         e
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">

        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mn>
      250
     </mn>
    </math></span> segments are studied in more detail. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0007">7</a>(a) depicts the piecewise linear characteristic curve of the spring force and Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0007">7</a>(b) the admissible set for the damper force. The resulting trajectories of the states and damper force are illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0007">7</a>(c). The mean absolute deviance between the damper force trajectory of the NLP solution and the SSC solution is defined as <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0118.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0118.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0118" class="disp-formula-label">(57) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
      <mtr>
       <mtd>
        <msub>
         <mover>
          <mi>
           e
          </mi>
          <mo accent="false">
           ¯
          </mo>
         </mover>
         <mrow>

    </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0316.gif" alt="">

    </math></span> for the SSC solution and NLP solution, respectively. However, the value for the main cost function&nbsp;(<a href="#M0092">48</a>) is <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0317.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0317.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msubsup>
      <mi>
       J

        <mi mathvariant="normal">

     </msubsup><mo>

      <mn>
       2550.73
      </mn>
     </mrow><mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace><msup>
      <mrow>

       </mi>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mn>
        2
       </mn>
      </mrow>
     </msup><mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace><mrow>
      <mi mathvariant="normal">
       s
      </mi>
     </mrow>
    </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0318.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0318.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mrow>
      <msubsup>
       <mi>
        J
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          N
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          L
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          P
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msubsup>
      <mo>
       =
      </mo>
      <mrow>
       <mn>
        2549.86
       </mn>
      </mrow>
      <mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace>
      <msup>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         m
        </mi>
       </mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mn>
         2
        </mn>
       </mrow>
      </msup>
      <mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace>
      <mrow>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        s
       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </mrow>
    </math></span> for the SSC solution and NLP solution, respectively. Thus, the SSC objective value is higher but the mean deviance in the steady-state position error is lower. The reason for this is that the cost function is quadratic in the errors which penalises large errors unevenly more than small errors. As illustrated in the top subplot of Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0007">7</a>, the position of the NLP solution reaches the steady-state position faster however with an overshoot which slowly reduces. Thus, the larger errors at the beginning are reduced more quickly resulting in a lower cost function value. However, the mean position error, which is a better metric for the actual goal of minimising the deviance from the steady-state position, is worse than for the SSC solution. Although an objective penalising the absolute value of the errors would be more adequate, it is not used since it would prevent continuous differentiability of the objective function. Nevertheless, both algorithms reach the steady-state position&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0319.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0319.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       x
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> in about 3 s resulting in similar state trajectories. The trajectories of the auxiliary variables verify correct switching at <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0320.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0320.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mi>
      x
     </mi><mo>
      =
     </mo><msub>
      <munder>
       <mi>
        x
       </mi>
       <mo>
        _
       </mo>
      </munder>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         r
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mo>
      −
     </mo><mn>
      5
     </mn><mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace><mrow>
      <mi mathvariant="normal">
       m
      </mi>
     </mrow>
    </math></span> and <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0321.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0321.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mi>
      v
     </mi><mo>
      =
     </mo><msub>
      <mi>
       v
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         r
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mn>
      0
     </mn><mfrac>
      <mrow>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        m
       </mi>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        s
       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </mfrac>
    </math></span> for the position and velocity, respectively. Furthermore, Figure <a href="#F0007">7</a>(a,b) shows that the spring forces lie on the characteristic line and the computed damper forces lie within the admissible set proving the compliance of the prescribed constraints. The bang-bang-like control strategy confirms correctness since it is expected due to the main objective&nbsp;(<a href="#M0092">48</a>), which demands to reduce the errors as fast as possible. With <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0322.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0322.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mi>
      q
     </mi><mo>
      =
     </mo><mrow>
      <mn>
       4
      </mn>
     </mrow>
    </math></span> superordinate iterations, the SSC method required a total optimisation time of <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">

    <span class="figViewerTitle">Space splitting convexification: a local solution method for nonconvex optimal control problems</span>
    <div class="articleAuthors articleInfoSection">

      All authors

  <div class="hidden rs_skip" id="figureFootNote-F0007">
   <div class="figureFootNote-F0007"></div>
  </div>
  <p></p>
  <p>Subsequently, the remaining results of Table&nbsp;<button class="ref showTableEventRef" data-id="T0003">3</button> are analysed to identify tendencies. As stated in Section&nbsp;2.2.1, the additional objective terms&nbsp;(55b) represent a relaxation of the constraints comparable with slack variables. Besides serving as feedback for determining convergence, this relaxation provides robustness regarding the initialisation. This is reflected in the results by a successful convergence of the SSC algorithm in 100% of the test cases, even though a rather poor initial guess was used. The accuracy of the computed solutions is evaluated using the mean values of the main cost function&nbsp;(<a href="#M0092">48</a>) and of the averaged errors&nbsp;(<a href="#M0118">57</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0119">58</a>) defined as <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0120.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0120.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0120" class="disp-formula-label">(59) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

          </mn>
         </mrow>
         <mrow>
          <mn>

          </mn>
         </mrow>
        </munderover>
        <msub>

          </mo>

         <mrow>

           <mi mathvariant="normal">

           </mi>
          </mrow>
          <mo>

          </mo>
          <mi>

          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </msub>
        <mo>
