        </mo>
       </mtd>
      </mtr>
     </mtable>
    </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0120" class="disp-formula-label">(59) </span></span></span></span>These values represent the respective mean value over all 10 OPs, due to 10 different initial values, for one specified number of collocation segments&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0331.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0331.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       n
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         e
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         g
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span>. With&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0332.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0332.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mover>
      <msub>
       <mover>
        <mi>
         e
        </mi>
        <mo accent="false">
         ¯
        </mo>
       </mover>
       <mrow>
        <msub>
         <mi>
          F
         </mi>
         <mrow>
          <mi>
           d
          </mi>
         </mrow>
        </msub>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
      <mo accent="false">
       ¯
      </mo>
     </mover><mo>
      ≤
     </mo><mrow>
      <mn>
       3.51
      </mn>
     </mrow><mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace><mrow>
      <mi mathvariant="normal">
       N
      </mi>
     </mrow>
    </math></span> being small compared to the domain of <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0333.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0333.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       F
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mi>
        d
       </mi>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span>, the control trajectories of the SSC approach are close to the trajectories computed by the NLP solver. The small deviation of the mean values in&nbsp;(<a href="#M0120">59</a>) between the SSC solution and the NLP solution indicates that both algorithms converged to a similar solution. Considering the mean value&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0334.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0334.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mover>
       <mi>
        J
       </mi>
       <mo accent="false">
        ¯
       </mo>
      </mover>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> of the main objective function, the NLP solver yields lower objective values than the SSC algorithm. As previously discussed, the mean deviance&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0335.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0335.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mover>
      <msub>
       <mover>
        <mi>
         e
        </mi>
        <mo accent="false">
         ¯
        </mo>
       </mover>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
      <mo accent="false">
       ¯
      </mo>
     </mover>
    </math></span> from the steady-state position is smaller when using the SSC algorithm.</p>
  <p>The SSC approach greatly reduces the overall computation time&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0336.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0336.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msubsup>
      <mi>
       t
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        Σ
       </mi>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         S
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         S
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         C
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msubsup>
    </math></span> and requires up to only&nbsp;18.20% of the computation time needed by the NLP solver. The time advantage of the SSC algorithm over the NLP optimiser will be even bigger for asymmetric zonally convex damper sets. Such asymmetric sets require additional discontinuities in the NLP problem but can be easily implemented within the SSC procedure by using differing parameters for the individual convex subsets. As mentioned in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2004">2.4</a>, various aspects influence the runtime of the SSC algorithm which is reflected in the results: With rising number of collocation segments, the mean solution time increases and the computation time of SSC increases less than the NLP&nbsp;solution time. Another mentioned effect on runtime is the quality of the initial guess. The provided guess with zero vectors is of varying quality for the individual initial value conditions. A better initial guess in terms of the correct signs of the state trajectories reduces the number of superordinate iterations and thus the overall computation time. Hence, the sensitivity in regards to the initial guess is elaborated in the following section.</p>
  <p>The pure optimisation time&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0337.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0337.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msubsup>
      <mi>
       t
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         o
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         p
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
       </mrow>
       <mo>
        ,
       </mo>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        Σ
       </mi>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         S
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         S
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         C
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msubsup>
    </math></span> reduces up to&nbsp;6.45% of the corresponding NLP time and is generally significantly shorter than its overall computation time&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0338.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0338.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msubsup>
      <mi>
       t
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mi mathvariant="normal">
        Σ
       </mi>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         S
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         S
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         C
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msubsup>
    </math></span>. Since the projection step of the SSC algorithm employs only simple computations using minimum and maximum functions with linear time complexity, the time spent outside of the QP solver, which solves convex QP-problems in polynomial time, seems quite long. Unfortunately, substantial time losses occur at building the updated optimisation model via <i>JuMP</i> and the <i>Gurobi</i>-wrapper. For future implementations, it is advisable to implement the SSC algorithm via C-code to circumvent this problem and minimise the overall computation time.</p>
 </div>
 <div id="S003-S2003" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i151">3.3. Influence of initial guess on results</h3>
  <p>In this section, the OPs&nbsp;(<a href="#M0096">51</a>) and&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55</a>) are modified to consider the nonlinear spring characteristic with three piecewise linear segments depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0005">5b</a>. The NLP problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0096">51</a>) is adjusted by replacing the spring force&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0339.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0339.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msubsup>

    </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0121" class="disp-formula-label">(60) </span></span></span></span>using the smooth maximum function <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0122.gif" alt="">

    </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0122" class="disp-formula-label">(61) </span></span></span></span>The adaptation of the QP problem&nbsp;(<a href="#M0109">55</a>) requires slightly more changes.     </math><span class="mathjaxLabel"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0123" class="disp-formula-label">(62) </span></span></span></span>Thus, the position space is bisected into a region below and a region above&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0340.gif" alt="">

    <math>
     <mi>
      x
     </mi><mo>
      =
     </mo><msub>
      <munder>
       <mi>
        x
       </mi>
       <mo>
        _
       </mo>
      </munder>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         r
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span>, whereas the upper region is again bisected into a region below and above&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0341.gif" alt="">

    <math>
     <mi>
      x
     </mi><mo>
      =
     </mo><msub>
      <mover>
       <mi>
        x
       </mi>

        ¯
       </mo>
      </mover>
      <mrow>

        <mi mathvariant="normal">

        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">

        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span>. Compared to&nbsp;(<a href="#M0106">54</a>), the update procedure remains unchanged for the decision variables of the inputs, states and auxiliary velocities: <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image disp-formula rs_preserve">

     <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">

    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0135.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_m0135.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"><span class="disp_formula_label_div"><span id="M0135" class="disp-formula-label">(65) </span></span></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula disp-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mtable columnalign="right left right left right left right left right left right left" rowspacing="3pt" columnspacing="0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em 2em 0.278em">
      <mtr>
       <mtd>
        <msub>
         <mover>
          <mi>
           l
          </mi>
          <mo accent="false">

  <p>In order to analyse the effect of the initialisation on the computed solution, several initial guesses are fed to the SSC algorithm aiming at solving the OP with initial value&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0344.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0344.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         x
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         v
        </mi>
       </mrow>
       <mo>
        ,
       </mo>
       <mn>
        1
       </mn>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> considering <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>

    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0345.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>

    <math>

       q

       <mrow>

        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         a
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">

       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mn>

    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       k
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">

        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">

        <mi mathvariant="normal">

     </mo><mo fence="false">

     </mo><mn>

     </mn><mo>

     </mn><mo>

      }
     </mo>
    </math></span> which are fed to the SSC update routine. The computations are compared to the results of the NLP problem which is initialised with the same guesses. The results of the individual optimisations are listed in Table&nbsp;<button class="ref showTableEventRef" data-id="T0004">4</button>. As Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0008">8</a>(a,b) indicates for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0350.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0350.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       k
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         n
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mn>
      0
     </mn>
    </math></span>, all solutions satisfy the prescribed constraints: The spring forces lie on the piecewise linear branches and the damper forces are within the admissible area. Considering the objective value&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0351.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0351.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       J
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> and mean error&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0352.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0352.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mover>
       <mi>
        e
       </mi>
       <mo accent="false">
        ¯
       </mo>
      </mover>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> in Table&nbsp;<button class="ref showTableEventRef" data-id="T0004">4</button>, the NLP solver converges to the same solution independently which initial guess is supplied. Thus, it is assumed that the computed NLP solution represents the global optimum or is at least very close to it. However, initialisation can have a massive impact on the computation time. Generally, the guesses close to the solution result in shorter computation times. It is striking that both algorithms have the most difficulty converging for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0353.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0353.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       k
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         n
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mn>
      0.5
     </mn>
    </math></span> which is not the guess with the biggest difference to the optimal solution. The SSC algorithm converges significantly faster than the NLP solver for all initial guesses. The number of superordinate iterations required by the SSC algorithm is small for good initial guesses. As for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0354.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0354.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       k
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         n
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mn>
      0.5
     </mn>
    </math></span>, a high number of superordinate iterations can still yield a faster convergence compared to the NLP solver. As already mentioned, the SSC algorithm represents a local method and does not necessarily provide the global optimum, which is reflected in the results. Considering the objective value&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0355.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0355.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       J
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> and mean error&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0356.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0356.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mover>
       <mi>
        e
       </mi>
       <mo accent="false">
        ¯
       </mo>
      </mover>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span>, only the SSC solutions for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0357.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0357.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       k
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         n
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      ≥
     </mo><mn>
      0.5
     </mn>
    </math></span> are roughly in the vicinity of the global solution. The mean deviance between the input trajectories&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0358.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0358.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mover>
       <mi>
        e
       </mi>
       <mo accent="false">
        ¯
       </mo>
      </mover>
      <mrow>
       <msub>
        <mi>
         F
        </mi>
        <mrow>
         <mi>
          d
         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </msub>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> is then rather small. Even though the SSC solutions may not represent the global optimum, the solutions satisfy the prescribed constraints since <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0359.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0359.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mi>
      q
     </mi><mo>
      &lt;
     </mo><msub>
      <mi>
       q
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         m
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         a
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         x
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span>. Thus, they represent a local solution of the piecewise linear problem, which corresponds to the original problem for the example at hand. The results for <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0360.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0360.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       k
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         n
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         t
        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      =
     </mo><mo fence="false">
      {
     </mo><mn>
      0.95
     </mn><mo>
      ,
     </mo><mn>
      1.0
     </mn><mo>
      ,
     </mo><mn>
      1.05
     </mn><mo fence="false">
      }
     </mo>
    </math></span> confirm that the SSC algorithm converges to the global optimum if the initial guess is in a close vicinity of it.</p>

    <div class="short-legend">
     <h3><p class="captionText"><span class="captionLabel">Table 4. </span> Analysis of sensitivity regarding initial guess.</p></h3>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div class="tableDownloadOption" data-hascsvlnk="false" id="T0004-table-wrapper">
    <a data-id="T0004" class="downloadButton btn btn-sm displaySizeTable" href="#" role="button">Display Table</a>
   </div>
  </div>
  <p></p>
  <p>As mentioned in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2004">2.4</a>, increasing the number of space divisions to depict the three-segmented spring raises computation time.  </div>
 <div id="S003-S2004" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2">
  <h3 class="section-heading-3" id="_i169">3.4. Rotated space splitting</h3>
  <p>As elaborated in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S002-S2003-S3001">2.3.1</a>, some sets require to be split using a rotated straight line. Without going into detail, the approach is applied to the example of a hanging SMO with&nbsp;fully linear spring presented in Section&nbsp;<a href="#S003-S2001">3.1</a>. The OP is parametrised with initial value&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0384.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0384.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mtext mathvariant="bold">
         x
        </mtext>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         v
        </mi>
       </mrow>
       <mo>
        ,
       </mo>
       <mn>
        1
       </mn>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> and&nbsp;<span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0385.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0385.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mrow>
      <msub>
       <mi>
        n
       </mi>
       <mrow>
        <mrow>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">
          s
         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">

         </mi>
         <mi mathvariant="normal">

         </mi>
        </mrow>
       </mrow>
      </msub>
      <mo>

      </mo>
      <mn>
       250
      </mn>
     </mrow>
    </math></span> collocation segments. The damper set is rotated by <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0386.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0386.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <mi>
      φ
     </mi><mo>
      =
     </mo><msup>
      <mn>
       7
      </mn>
      <mrow>
       <mo>
        ∘
       </mo>
      </mrow>
     </msup>
    </math></span> resulting in the set depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0009">9</a>(a). This is implemented by applying the changes&nbsp;(<a href="#M0071">36</a>) to the convex QP problem with fully linear spring. As depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0009">9</a>(a), the SSC algorithm computes damper forces which all lie within the admissible area. Although this example represents an artificial use-case, the corresponding position trajectories in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#F0009">9</a>(b) prove that the rotated set yields a reduction of the objective. Starting with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0387.gif" alt="">

      <mi>

        <mi mathvariant="normal">

       </mo>

       </mn>
      </mrow>

      &lt;
     </mo><msub>
      <mi>

      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         s
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">

        </mi>
       </mrow>
      </mrow>
     </msub>
    </math></span> in a compression phase with <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0388.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0388.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       v
      </mi>
      <mrow>
       <mrow>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         i
        </mi>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">
         v
        </mi>
       </mrow>
       <mo>
        ,
       </mo>
       <mn>
        1
       </mn>
      </mrow>
     </msub><mo>
      &lt;
     </mo><mn>
      0
     </mn>
    </math></span>, the mass is first decelerated and then accelerated using <span class="NLM_disp-formula-image inline-formula rs_preserve">
    <noscript>
     <img src="/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0389.gif" alt="">
    </noscript><img src="//:0" alt="" class="mml-formula" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;image&quot;, &quot;src&quot; : &quot;/na101/home/literatum/publisher/tandf/journals/content/tcon20/2023/tcon20.v096.i02/00207179.2021.2004449/20230130/images/tcon_a_2004449_ilm0389.gif&quot;}"><span class="mml-formula"></span></span><span class="NLM_disp-formula inline-formula rs_preserve"><img src="//:0" alt="" data-formula-source="{&quot;type&quot; : &quot;mathjax&quot;}">
    <math>
     <msub>
      <mi>
       F
      </mi>
      <mi>
       d
      </mi>
     </msub><mo>
      &lt;
     </mo><mn>
      0
     </mn>
    </math></span> at <i>v</i>&gt;0, hence active forces. These active forces enable a faster attainment of the steady-state position. Due to the similarity to the previous examples, no further discussion is given.</p>
 </div>
</div>
<div id="S004" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec-type_conclusions NLM_sec_level_1">
 <h2 id="_i170" class="section-heading-2">4. Conclusions</h2>
 <p>This article has presented a novel local solution method for efficiently solving nonconvex optimal control problems. Splitting the space of inputs and states enables the formulation of QP subproblems which are solved iteratively. The method is capable of considering two types of nonconvexities: ZCSs and equality constraints with possibly multiple univariate nonlinearities. The approach decomposes the nonconvexities into affine parts which are linked appropriately to approximate the original problem with scalable approximation error. It has been shown that the SSC algorithm converges to a local optimum of this approximated problem. The quality of the solution depends on the initial guess. For good initial guesses, the method converges to solutions close to the global one. A comparison of this successive convexification technique with other existing methods has been given, highlighting the advantages SSC provides.</p>
 <div class="figure figureViewer" id="F0009">
  <div class="hidden figureViewerArticleInfo">
   <span class="figViewerTitle">Space splitting convexification: a local solution method for nonconvex optimal control problems</span>
   <div class="articleAuthors articleInfoSection">
    <div class="authorsHeading">
     All authors
    </div>
    <div class="authors">

 </div>
 <div class="hidden rs_skip" id="figureFootNote-F0009">
  <div class="figureFootNote-F0009"></div>
 </div>
 <p></p>
 <p>Subsequently, possible directions for future research are disclosed. Even though it would not change the algorithm, using nondifferentiable constraint qualifications&nbsp;(Ye,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0058" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2004</a></span>) could potentially avoid the AVC-smoothing required for continuous differentiability regarding the convergence proof. Due to the low computation time and robust convergence, the SSC method seems to be a promising approach for real-time optimal control applications. In this context, using MPC could provide sufficiently good initial guesses&nbsp;(Diehl et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0012" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2005</a></span>; Gros et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0018" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2020</a></span>) resulting in good SSC solutions. In order to enhance applicability, the SSC approach could be combined with other iterative linearisation schemes like&nbsp;(Carvalho et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0006" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2013</a></span>; Liniger et al., <span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0029" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2015</a></span>; Mao et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0032" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2017</a></span>; Simon et al.,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0050" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2013</a></span>) which could enable considering collision avoidance constraints. Furthermore, extending the SSC approach to bivariate nonlinearities in equality constraints would enlarge the possible scope of applications. Moreover, applying a more sophisticated updating procedure for the penalty parameter would improve computation times&nbsp;(Maratos,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0034" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1978</a></span>; Mayne &amp;&nbsp;Maratos,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0036" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>1979</a></span>; Nocedal &amp;&nbsp;Wright,&nbsp;<span class="ref-lnk lazy-ref"><a data-rid="CIT0039" data-reflink="_i173 _i174" href="#"><span class="off-screen">Citation</span>2006</a></span>). For applications with real-time capability requirement, it is recommended to implement the algorithm via tailored C-code to avoid the overhead introduced by the high-level routines of <i>JuMP</i> and the <i>Gurobi</i>-wrapper. Then, the required time for the updating step can be greatly reduced to linear time complexity resulting in shorter overall computation times.</p>
</div>
